Chapter X
Of the Faith of the Fathers

7.text: Dim face of Beauty haunting all the world,

12.text:
Fair face of Beauty all too fair to see,
Where the lost stars adown the heavens are

30.text: Beauty, sad face of Beauty, Mystery, Wonder,

36.text:
What are these dreams to foolish babbling
men

40.text: Who cry with little noises 'neath the thunder

56.text:
Fiona Macleod
It was out in the country, far from home,

75.text:
far from my foster home, on a dark Sunday
night.

79.text:
The road wandered from our rambling log-house
up the stony bed of a creek, past wheat and

85.text:
corn, until we could hear dimly across the
fields a rhythmic cadence of song,—soft,

92.text:
thrilling, powerful, that swelled and died
sorrowfully in our ears.

100.text:
I was a country schoolteacher then, fresh
from the East, and had never seen a Southern

105.text:
Negro revival.
To be sure, we in Berkshire were not perhaps

109.text:
as stiff and formal as they in Suffolk of
olden time; yet we were very quiet and subdued,

117.text:
and I know not what would have happened those
clear Sabbath mornings had some one punctuated

122.text:
the sermon with a wild scream, or interrupted
the long prayer with a loud Amen!

129.text:
And so most striking to me, as I approached
the village and the little plain church perched

135.text:
aloft, was the air of intense excitement that
possessed that mass of black folk.

141.text:
A sort of suppressed terror hung in the air
and seemed to seize us,—a pythian madness,

148.text:
a demoniac possession, that lent terrible
reality to song and word.

153.text:
The black and massive form of the preacher
swayed and quivered as the words crowded to

157.text:
his lips and flew at us in singular eloquence.
The people moaned and fluttered, and then

164.text:
the gaunt-cheeked brown woman beside me suddenly
leaped straight into the air and shrieked

169.text:
like a lost soul, while round about came wail
and groan and outcry, and a scene of human

177.text:
passion such as I had never conceived before.
Those who have not thus witnessed the frenzy

184.text:
of a Negro revival in the untouched backwoods
of the South can but dimly realize the religious

190.text:
feeling of the slave; as described, such scenes
appear grotesque and funny, but as seen they

198.text:
are awful.
Three things characterized this religion of

204.text:
the slave,—the Preacher, the Music, and
the Frenzy.

211.text:
The Preacher is the most unique personality
developed by the Negro on American soil.

216.text:
A leader, a politician, an orator, a "boss,"
an intriguer, an idealist,—all these he

224.text:
is, and ever, too, the centre of a group of
men, now twenty, now a thousand in number.

232.text:
The combination of a certain adroitness with
deep-seated earnestness, of tact with consummate

237.text:
ability, gave him his preeminence, and helps
him maintain it.

242.text:
The type, of course, varies according to time
and place, from the West Indies in the sixteenth

247.text:
century to New England in the nineteenth,
and from the Mississippi bottoms to cities

252.text:
like New Orleans or New York.
The Music of Negro religion is that plaintive

258.text:
rhythmic melody, with its touching minor cadences,
which, despite caricature and defilement,

265.text:
still remains the most original and beautiful
expression of human life and longing yet born

270.text:
on American soil.
Sprung from the African forests, where its

274.text:
counterpart can still be heard, it was adapted,
changed, and intensified by the tragic soul-life

281.text:
of the slave, until, under the stress of law
and whip, it became the one true expression

287.text:
of a people's sorrow, despair, and hope.
Finally the Frenzy of "Shouting," when the

296.text:
Spirit of the Lord passed by, and, seizing
the devotee, made him mad with supernatural

301.text:
joy, was the last essential of Negro religion
and the one more devoutly believed in than

307.text:
all the rest.
It varied in expression from the silent rapt

311.text:
countenance or the low murmur and moan to
the mad abandon of physical fervor,—the

317.text:
stamping, shrieking, and shouting, the rushing
to and fro and wild waving of arms, the weeping

323.text:
and laughing, the vision and the trance.
All this is nothing new in the world, but

329.text:
old as religion, as Delphi and Endor.
And so firm a hold did it have on the Negro,

336.text:
that many generations firmly believed that
without this visible manifestation of the

341.text:
God there could be no true communion with
the Invisible.

346.text:
These were the characteristics of Negro religious
life as developed up to the time of Emancipation.

352.text:
Since under the peculiar circumstances of
the black man's environment they were the

356.text:
one expression of his higher life, they are
of deep interest to the student of his development,

362.text:
both socially and psychologically.
Numerous are the attractive lines of inquiry

367.text:
that here group themselves.
What did slavery mean to the African savage?

373.text:
What was his attitude toward the World and
Life?

377.text:
What seemed to him good and evil,—God and
Devil?

383.text:
Whither went his longings and strivings, and
wherefore were his heart-burnings and disappointments?

390.text:
Answers to such questions can come only from
a study of Negro religion as a development,

395.text:
through its gradual changes from the heathenism
of the Gold Coast to the institutional Negro

401.text:
church of Chicago.
Moreover, the religious growth of millions

407.text:
of men, even though they be slaves, cannot
be without potent influence upon their contemporaries.

414.text:
The Methodists and Baptists of America owe
much of their condition to the silent but

419.text:
potent influence of their millions of Negro
converts. Especially is this noticeable in

425.text:
the South, where theology and religious philosophy
are on this account a long way behind the

431.text:
North, and where the religion of the poor
whites is a plain copy of Negro thought and

436.text:
methods.
The mass of "gospel" hymns which has swept

441.text:
through American churches and well-nigh ruined
our sense of song consists largely of debased

447.text:
imitations of Negro melodies made by ears
that caught the jingle but not the music,

453.text:
the body but not the soul, of the Jubilee
songs.

458.text:
It is thus clear that the study of Negro religion
is not only a vital part of the history of

464.text:
the Negro in America, but no uninteresting
part of American history.

471.text:
The Negro church of to-day is the social centre
of Negro life in the United States, and the

476.text:
most characteristic expression of African
character.

480.text:
Take a typical church in a small Virginia
town: it is the "First Baptist"—a roomy

488.text:
brick edifice seating five hundred or more
persons, tastefully finished in Georgia pine,

493.text:
with a carpet, a small organ, and stained-glass
windows.

499.text:
Underneath is a large assembly room with benches.
This building is the central club-house of

505.text:
a community of a thousand or more Negroes.
Various organizations meet here,—the church

511.text:
proper, the Sunday-school, two or three insurance
societies, women's societies, secret societies,

519.text:
and mass meetings of various kinds.
Entertainments, suppers, and lectures are

523.text:
held beside the five or six regular weekly
religious services.

529.text:
Considerable sums of money are collected and
expended here, employment is found for the

533.text:
idle, strangers are introduced, news is disseminated
and charity distributed. At the same time

541.text:
this social, intellectual, and economic centre
is a religious centre of great power.

547.text:
Depravity, Sin, Redemption, Heaven, Hell,
and Damnation are preached twice a Sunday

554.text:
after the crops are laid by; and few indeed
of the community have the hardihood to withstand

560.text:
conversion.
Back of this more formal religion, the Church

564.text:
often stands as a real conserver of morals,
a strengthener of family life, and the final

571.text:
authority on what is Good and Right.
Thus one can see in the Negro church to-day,

578.text:
reproduced in microcosm, all the great world
from which the Negro is cut off by color-prejudice

585.text:
and social condition.
In the great city churches the same tendency

589.text:
is noticeable and in many respects emphasized.
A great church like the Bethel of Philadelphia

597.text:
has over eleven hundred members, an edifice
seating fifteen hundred persons and valued

605.text:
at one hundred thousand dollars, an annual
budget of five thousand dollars, and a government

613.text:
consisting of a pastor with several assisting
local preachers, an executive and legislative

618.text:
board, financial boards and tax collectors;
general church meetings for making laws; sub-divided

624.text:
groups led by class leaders, a company of
militia, and twenty-four auxiliary societies.

633.text:
The activity of a church like this is immense
and far-reaching, and the bishops who preside

637.text:
over these organizations throughout the land
are among the most powerful Negro rulers in

642.text:
the world.
Such churches are really governments of men,

648.text:
and consequently a little investigation reveals
the curious fact that, in the South, at least,

655.text:
practically every American Negro is a church
member.

659.text:
Some, to be sure, are not regularly enrolled,
and a few do not habitually attend services;

666.text:
but, practically, a proscribed people must
have a social centre, and that centre for

672.text:
this people is the Negro church.
The census of 1890 showed nearly twenty-four

678.text:
thousand Negro churches in the country, with
a total enrolled membership of over two and

683.text:
a half millions, or ten actual church members
to every twenty-eight persons, and in some

690.text:
Southern States one in every two persons.
Besides these there is the large number who,

698.text:
while not enrolled as members, attend and
take part in many of the activities of the

705.text:
church.
There is an organized Negro church for every

707.text:
sixty black families in the nation, and in
some States for every forty families, owning,

714.text:
on an average, a thousand dollars' worth of
property each, or nearly twenty-six million

718.text:
dollars in all.
Such, then, is the large development of the

722.text:
Negro church since Emancipation.
The question now is, What have been the successive

728.text:
steps of this social history and what are
the present tendencies?

733.text:
First, we must realize that no such institution
as the Negro church could rear itself without

739.text:
definite historical foundations.
These foundations we can find if we remember

744.text:
that the social history of the Negro did not
start in America.

749.text:
He was brought from a definite social environment,—the
polygamous clan life under the headship of

755.text:
the chief and the potent influence of the
priest.

759.text:
His religion was nature-worship, with profound
belief in invisible surrounding influences,

765.text:
good and bad, and his worship was through
incantation and sacrifice.

771.text:
The first rude change in this life was the
slave ship and the West Indian sugar-fields.

777.text:
The plantation organization replaced the clan
and tribe, and the white master replaced the

782.text:
chief with far greater and more despotic powers.
Forced and long-continued toil became the

791.text:
rule of life, the old ties of blood relationship
and kinship disappeared, and instead of the

799.text:
family appeared a new polygamy and polyandry,
which, in some cases, almost reached promiscuity.

805.text:
It was a terrific social revolution, and yet
some traces were retained of the former group

811.text:
life, and the chief remaining institution
was the Priest or Medicine-man.

816.text:
He early appeared on the plantation and found
his function as the healer of the sick, the

821.text:
interpreter of the Unknown, the comforter
of the sorrowing, the supernatural avenger

825.text:
of wrong, and the one who rudely but picturesquely
expressed the longing, disappointment, and

832.text:
resentment of a stolen and oppressed people.
Thus, as bard, physician, judge, and priest,

841.text:
within the narrow limits allowed by the slave
system, rose the Negro preacher, and under

846.text:
him the first church was not at first by any
means Christian nor definitely organized;

852.text:
rather it was an adaptation and mingling of
heathen rites among the members of each plantation,

858.text:
and roughly designated as Voodooism. Association
with the masters, missionary effort and motives

867.text:
of expediency gave these rites an early veneer
of Christianity, and after the lapse of many

873.text:
generations the Negro church became Christian.
Two characteristic things must be noticed

880.text:
in regard to the church. First, it became
almost entirely Baptist and Methodist in faith;

887.text:
secondly, as a social institution it antedated
by many decades the monogamic Negro home.

896.text:
From the very circumstances of its beginning,
the church was confined to the plantation,

901.text:
and consisted primarily of a series of disconnected
units; although, later on, some freedom of

906.text:
movement was allowed, still this geographical
limitation was always important and was one

913.text:
cause of the spread of the decentralized and
democratic Baptist faith among the slaves.

919.text:
At the same time, the visible rite of baptism
appealed strongly to their mystic temperament.

925.text:
To-day the Baptist Church is still largest
in membership among Negroes, and has a million

930.text:
and a half communicants.
Next in popularity came the churches organized

935.text:
in connection with the white neighboring churches,
chiefly Baptist and Methodist, with a few

941.text:
Episcopalian and others.
The Methodists still form the second greatest

946.text:
denomination, with nearly a million members.
The faith of these two leading denominations

952.text:
was more suited to the slave church from the
prominence they gave to religious feeling

957.text:
and fervor.
The Negro membership in other denominations

961.text:
has always been small and relatively unimportant,
although the Episcopalians and Presbyterians

968.text:
are gaining among the more intelligent classes
to-day, and the Catholic Church is making

973.text:
headway in certain sections.
After Emancipation, and still earlier in the

978.text:
North, the Negro churches largely severed
such affiliations as they had had with the

983.text:
white churches, either by choice or by compulsion.
The Baptist churches became independent, but

991.text:
the Methodists were compelled early to unite
for purposes of episcopal government.

996.text:
This gave rise to the great African Methodist
Church, the greatest Negro organization in

1000.text:
the world, to the Zion Church and the Colored
Methodist, and to the black conferences and

1006.text:
churches in this and other denominations.
The second fact noted, namely, that the Negro

1014.text:
church antedates the Negro home, leads to
an explanation of much that is paradoxical

1019.text:
in this communistic institution and in the
morals of its members.

1024.text:
But especially it leads us to regard this
institution as peculiarly the expression of

1030.text:
the inner ethical life of a people in a sense
seldom true elsewhere.

1035.text:
Let us turn, then, from the outer physical
development of the church to the more important

1039.text:
inner ethical life of the people who compose
it.

1043.text:
The Negro has already been pointed out many
times as a religious animal,—a being of

1049.text:
that deep emotional nature which turns instinctively
toward the supernatural.

1053.text:
Endowed with a rich tropical imagination and
a keen, delicate appreciation of Nature, the

1059.text:
transplanted African lived in a world animate
with gods and devils, elves and witches; full

1065.text:
of strange influences,—of Good to be implored,
of Evil to be propitiated.

1072.text:
Slavery, then, was to him the dark triumph
of Evil over him.

1077.text:
All the hateful powers of the Under-world
were striving against him, and a spirit of

1082.text:
revolt and revenge filled his heart.
He called up all the resources of heathenism

1088.text:
to aid,—exorcism and witch-craft, the mysterious
Obi worship with its barbarious rites, spells,

1095.text:
and blood-sacrifice even, now and then, of
human victims. Weird midnight orgies and mystic

1101.text:
conjurations were invoked, the witch-woman
and the voodoo-priest became the centre of

1106.text:
Negro group life, and that vein of vague superstition
which characterizes the unlettered Negro even

1112.text:
to-day was deepened and strengthened.
In spite, however, of such success as that

1119.text:
of the fierce Maroons, the Danish blacks,
and others, the spirit of revolt gradually

1125.text:
died away under the untiring energy and superior
strength of the slave masters. By the middle

1133.text:
of the eighteenth century the black slave
had sunk, with hushed murmurs, to his place

1138.text:
at the bottom of a new economic system, and
was unconsciously ripe for a new philosophy

1143.text:
of life.
Nothing suited his condition then better than

1148.text:
the doctrines of passive submission embodied
in the newly learned Christianity.

1155.text:
Slave masters early realized this, and cheerfully
aided religious propaganda within certain

1160.text:
bounds.
The long system of repression and degradation

1164.text:
of the Negro tended to emphasize the elements
of his character which made him a valuable

1169.text:
chattel: courtesy became humility, moral strength
degenerated into submission, and the exquisite

1178.text:
native appreciation of the beautiful became
an infinite capacity for dumb suffering.

1184.text:
The Negro, losing the joy of this world, eagerly
seized upon the offered conceptions of the

1190.text:
next; the avenging Spirit of the Lord enjoining
patience in this world, under sorrow and tribulation

1198.text:
until the Great Day when He should lead His
dark children home,—this became his comforting

1204.text:
dream.
His preacher repeated the prophecy, and his

1210.text:
"Children, we all shall be free
When the Lord shall appear!"

1216.text:
This deep religious fatalism, painted so beautifully
in "Uncle Tom," came soon to breed, as all

1223.text:
fatalistic faiths will, the sensualist side
by side with the martyr.

1229.text:
Under the lax moral life of the plantation,
where marriage was a farce, laziness a virtue,

1235.text:
and property a theft, a religion of resignation
and submission degenerated easily, in less

1241.text:
strenuous minds, into a philosophy of indulgence
and crime.

1247.text:
Many of the worst characteristics of the Negro
masses of to-day had their seed in this period

1252.text:
of the slave's ethical growth.
Here it was that the Home was ruined under

1258.text:
the very shadow of the Church, white and black;
here habits of shiftlessness took root, and

1266.text:
sullen hopelessness replaced hopeful strife.
With the beginning of the abolition movement

1274.text:
and the gradual growth of a class of free
Negroes came a change.

1279.text:
We often neglect the influence of the freedman
before the war, because of the paucity of

1283.text:
his numbers and the small weight he had in
the history of the nation.

1287.text:
But we must not forget that his chief influence
was internal,—was exerted on the black world;

1295.text:
and that there he was the ethical and social
leader. Huddled as he was in a few centres

1301.text:
like Philadelphia, New York, and New Orleans,
the masses of the freedmen sank into poverty

1306.text:
and listlessness; but not all of them.
The free Negro leader early arose and his

1314.text:
chief characteristic was intense earnestness
and deep feeling on the slavery question.

1322.text:
Freedom became to him a real thing and not
a dream.

1326.text:
His religion became darker and more intense,
and into his ethics crept a note of revenge,

1333.text:
into his songs a day of reckoning close at
hand.

1337.text:
The "Coming of the Lord" swept this side of
Death, and came to be a thing to be hoped

1342.text:
for in this day.
Through fugitive slaves and irrepressible

1347.text:
discussion this desire for freedom seized
the black millions still in bondage, and became

1353.text:
their one ideal of life.
The black bards caught new notes, and sometimes

1360.text:
"O Freedom, O Freedom, O Freedom over me!
Before I'll be a slave

1366.text:
I'll be buried in my grave,
And go home to my Lord

1369.text:
And be free."
For fifty years Negro religion thus transformed

1374.text:
itself and identified itself with the dream
of Abolition, until that which was a radical

1379.text:
fad in the white North and an anarchistic
plot in the white South had become a religion

1385.text:
to the black world.
Thus, when Emancipation finally came, it seemed

1390.text:
to the freedman a literal Coming of the Lord.
His fervid imagination was stirred as never

1397.text:
before, by the tramp of armies, the blood
and dust of battle, and the wail and whirl

1403.text:
of social upheaval.
He stood dumb and motionless before the whirlwind:

1409.text:
what had he to do with it?
Was it not the Lord's doing, and marvellous

1413.text:
in his eyes?
Joyed and bewildered with what came, he stood

1418.text:
awaiting new wonders till the inevitable Age
of Reaction swept over the nation and brought

1424.text:
the crisis of to-day.
It is difficult to explain clearly the present

1430.text:
critical stage of Negro religion.
First, we must remember that living as the

1435.text:
blacks do in close contact with a great modern
nation, and sharing, although imperfectly,

1441.text:
the soul-life of that nation, they must necessarily
be affected more or less directly by all the

1448.text:
religious and ethical forces that are to-day
moving the United States.

1453.text:
These questions and movements are, however,
overshadowed and dwarfed by the (to them)

1460.text:
all-important question of their civil, political,
and economic status. They must perpetually

1467.text:
discuss the "Negro Problem,"—must live,
move, and have their being in it, and interpret

1474.text:
all else in its light or darkness.
With this come, too, peculiar problems of

1480.text:
their inner life,—of the status of women,
the maintenance of Home, the training of children,

1485.text:
the accumulation of wealth, and the prevention
of crime.

1490.text:
All this must mean a time of intense ethical
ferment, of religious heart-searching and

1496.text:
intellectual unrest.
From the double life every American Negro

1502.text:
must live, as a Negro and as an American,
as swept on by the current of the nineteenth

1508.text:
while yet struggling in the eddies of the
fifteenth century,—from this must arise

1514.text:
a painful self-consciousness, an almost morbid
sense of personality and a moral hesitancy

1522.text:
which is fatal to self-confidence.
The worlds within and without the Veil of

1527.text:
Color are changing, and changing rapidly,
but not at the same rate, not in the same

1534.text:
way; and this must produce a peculiar wrenching
of the soul, a peculiar sense of doubt and

1541.text:
bewilderment.
Such a double life, with double thoughts,

1545.text:
double duties, and double social classes,
must give rise to double words and double

1550.text:
ideals, and tempt the mind to pretence or
revolt, to hypocrisy or radicalism.

1560.text:
In some such doubtful words and phrases can
one perhaps most clearly picture the peculiar

1565.text:
ethical paradox that faces the Negro of to-day
and is tingeing and changing his religious

1571.text:
life.
Feeling that his rights and his dearest ideals

1575.text:
are being trampled upon, that the public conscience
is ever more deaf to his righteous appeal,

1583.text:
and that all the reactionary forces of prejudice,
greed, and revenge are daily gaining new strength

1588.text:
and fresh allies, the Negro faces no enviable
dilemma. Conscious of his impotence, and pessimistic,

1597.text:
he often becomes bitter and vindictive; and
his religion, instead of a worship, is a complaint

1603.text:
and a curse, a wail rather than a hope, a
sneer rather than a faith. On the other hand,

1610.text:
another type of mind, shrewder and keener
and more tortuous too, sees in the very strength

1616.text:
of the anti-Negro movement its patent weaknesses,
and with Jesuitic casuistry is deterred by

1625.text:
no ethical considerations in the endeavor
to turn this weakness to the black man's strength.

1631.text:
Thus we have two great and hardly reconcilable
streams of thought and ethical strivings;

1639.text:
the danger of the one lies in anarchy, that
of the other in hypocrisy.

1644.text:
The one type of Negro stands almost ready
to curse God and die, and the other is too

1650.text:
often found a traitor to right and a coward
before force; the one is wedded to ideals

1657.text:
remote, whimsical, perhaps impossible of realization;
the other forgets that life is more than meat

1665.text:
and the body more than raiment.
But, after all, is not this simply the writhing

1670.text:
of the age translated into black,—the triumph
of the Lie which today, with its false culture,

1677.text:
faces the hideousness of the anarchist assassin?
To-day the two groups of Negroes, the one

1684.text:
in the North, the other in the South, represent
these divergent ethical tendencies, the first

1691.text:
tending toward radicalism, the other toward
hypocritical compromise. It is no idle regret

1699.text:
with which the white South mourns the loss
of the old-time Negro,—the frank, honest,

1704.text:
simple old servant who stood for the earlier
religious age of submission and humility.

1710.text:
With all his laziness and lack of many elements
of true manhood, he was at least open-hearted,

1715.text:
faithful, and sincere.
To-day he is gone, but who is to blame for

1721.text:
his going?
Is it not those very persons who mourn for

1724.text:
him? Is it not the tendency, born of Reconstruction
and Reaction, to found a society on lawlessness

1733.text:
and deception, to tamper with the moral fibre
of a naturally honest and straightforward

1739.text:
people until the whites threaten to become
ungovernable tyrants and the blacks criminals

1746.text:
and hypocrites? Deception is the natural defence
of the weak against the strong, and the South

1752.text:
used it for many years against its conquerors;
to-day it must be prepared to see its black

1757.text:
proletariat turn that same two-edged weapon
against itself.

1762.text:
And how natural this is!
The death of Denmark Vesey and Nat Turner

1766.text:
proved long since to the Negro the present
hopelessness of physical defence.

1772.text:
Political defence is becoming less and less
available, and economic defence is still only

1776.text:
partially effective.
But there is a patent defence at hand,—the

1782.text:
defence of deception and flattery, of cajoling
and lying.

1787.text:
It is the same defence which peasants of the
Middle Age used and which left its stamp on

1792.text:
their character for centuries.
To-day the young Negro of the South who would

1797.text:
succeed cannot be frank and outspoken, honest
and self-assertive, but rather he is daily

1804.text:
tempted to be silent and wary, politic and
sly; he must flatter and be pleasant, endure

1811.text:
petty insults with a smile, shut his eyes
to wrong; in too many cases he sees positive

1818.text:
personal advantage in deception and lying.
His real thoughts, his real aspirations, must

1825.text:
be guarded in whispers; he must not criticise,
he must not complain.

1830.text:
Patience, humility, and adroitness must, in
these growing black youth, replace impulse,

1838.text:
manliness, and courage.
With this sacrifice there is an economic opening,

1845.text:
and perhaps peace and some prosperity.
Without this there is riot, migration, or

1853.text:
crime.
Nor is this situation peculiar to the Southern

1856.text:
United States, is it not rather the only method
by which undeveloped races have gained the

1861.text:
right to share modern culture?
The price of culture is a Lie.

1870.text:
On the other hand, in the North the tendency
is to emphasize the radicalism of the Negro.

1875.text:
Driven from his birthright in the South by
a situation at which every fibre of his more

1880.text:
outspoken and assertive nature revolts, he
finds himself in a land where he can scarcely

1886.text:
earn a decent living amid the harsh competition
and the color discrimination. At the same

1893.text:
time, through schools and periodicals, discussions
and lectures, he is intellectually quickened

1900.text:
and awakened.
The soul, long pent up and dwarfed, suddenly

1906.text:
expands in new-found freedom.
What wonder that every tendency is to excess,—radical

1912.text:
complaint, radical remedies, bitter denunciation
or angry silence.

1918.text:
Some sink, some rise. The criminal and the
sensualist leave the church for the gambling-hell

1926.text:
and the brothel, and fill the slums of Chicago
and Baltimore; the better classes segregate

1932.text:
themselves from the group-life of both white
and black, and form an aristocracy, cultured

1938.text:
but pessimistic, whose bitter criticism stings
while it points out no way of escape.

1945.text:
They despise the submission and subserviency
of the Southern Negroes, but offer no other

1950.text:
means by which a poor and oppressed minority
can exist side by side with its masters.

1957.text:
Feeling deeply and keenly the tendencies and
opportunities of the age in which they live,

1962.text:
their souls are bitter at the fate which drops
the Veil between; and the very fact that this

1968.text:
bitterness is natural and justifiable only
serves to intensify it and make it more maddening.

1979.text:
Between the two extreme types of ethical attitude
which I have thus sought to make clear wavers

1984.text:
the mass of the millions of Negroes, North
and South; and their religious life and activity

1990.text:
partake of this social conflict within their
ranks.

1994.text:
Their churches are differentiating,—now
into groups of cold, fashionable devotees,

2000.text:
in no way distinguishable from similar white
groups save in color of skin; now into large

2006.text:
social and business institutions catering
to the desire for information and amusement

2011.text:
of their members, warily avoiding unpleasant
questions both within and without the black

2017.text:
world, and preaching in effect if not in word:
Dum vivimus, vivamus.

2023.text:
But back of this still broods silently the
deep religious feeling of the real Negro heart,

2029.text:
the stirring, unguided might of powerful human
souls who have lost the guiding star of the

2037.text:
past and seek in the great night a new religious
ideal.

2043.text:
Some day the Awakening will come, when the
pent-up vigor of ten million souls shall sweep

2049.text:
irresistibly toward the Goal, out of the Valley
of the Shadow of Death, where all that makes

2056.text:
life worth living—Liberty, Justice, and
Right—is marked "For White People Only."

2066.text:
End of Chapter X
Chapter XI

2073.text: Of the Passing of the First-Born

2074.text:
O sister, sister, thy first-begotten,
The hands that cling and the feet that follow,

2086.text:
The voice of the child's blood crying yet,
WHO HATH REMEMBERED ME?

2093.text:
WHO HATH FORGOTTEN?
Thou hast forgotten, O summer swallow,

2098.text: But the world shall end when I forget.

2103.text:
Swinburne
"Unto you a child is born," sang the bit of

2131.text:
yellow paper that fluttered into my room one
brown October morning.

2136.text:
Then the fear of fatherhood mingled wildly
with the joy of creation; I wondered how it

2144.text:
looked and how it felt—what were its eyes,
and how its hair curled and crumpled itself.

2153.text:
And I thought in awe of her,—she who had
slept with Death to tear a man-child from

2158.text:
underneath her heart, while I was unconsciously
wandering.

2162.text:
I fled to my wife and child, repeating the
while to myself half wonderingly, "Wife and

2170.text:
child?
Wife and child?"—fled fast and faster than

2177.text:
boat and steam-car, and yet must ever impatiently
await them; away from the hard-voiced city,

2185.text:
away from the flickering sea into my own Berkshire
Hills that sit all sadly guarding the gates

2190.text:
of Massachusetts.
Up the stairs I ran to the wan mother and

2196.text:
whimpering babe, to the sanctuary on whose
altar a life at my bidding had offered itself

2202.text:
to win a life, and won.
What is this tiny formless thing, this newborn

2211.text:
wail from an unknown world,—all head and
voice?

2215.text:
I handle it curiously, and watch perplexed
its winking, breathing, and sneezing.

2222.text:
I did not love it then; it seemed a ludicrous
thing to love; but her I loved, my girl-mother,

2231.text:
she whom now I saw unfolding like the glory
of the morning—the transfigured woman.

2239.text:
Through her I came to love the wee thing,
as it grew strong; as its little soul unfolded

2246.text:
itself in twitter and cry and half-formed
word, and as its eyes caught the gleam and

2253.text:
flash of life.
How beautiful he was, with his olive-tinted

2260.text:
flesh and dark gold ringlets, his eyes of
mingled blue and brown, his perfect little

2266.text:
limbs, and the soft voluptuous roll which
the blood of Africa had moulded into his features!

2271.text:
I held him in my arms, after we had sped far
away from our Southern home,—held him, and

2278.text:
glanced at the hot red soil of Georgia and
the breathless city of a hundred hills, and

2285.text:
felt a vague unrest.
Why was his hair tinted with gold?

2293.text:
An evil omen was golden hair in my life.
Why had not the brown of his eyes crushed

2300.text:
out and killed the blue?—for brown were
his father's eyes, and his father's father's.

2306.text:
And thus in the Land of the Color-line I saw,
as it fell across my baby, the shadow of the

2315.text:
Veil.
Within the Veil was he born, said I; and there

2320.text:
within shall he live,—a Negro and a Negro's
son.

2326.text:
Holding in that little head—ah, bitterly!—he
unbowed pride of a hunted race, clinging with

2335.text:
that tiny dimpled hand—ah, wearily!—to
a hope not hopeless but unhopeful, and seeing

2344.text:
with those bright wondering eyes that peer
into my soul a land whose freedom is to us

2353.text:
a mockery and whose liberty a lie.
I saw the shadow of the Veil as it passed

2360.text:
over my baby, I saw the cold city towering
above the blood-red land.

2366.text:
I held my face beside his little cheek, showed
him the star-children and the twinkling lights

2372.text:
as they began to flash, and stilled with an
even-song the unvoiced terror of my life.

2380.text:
So sturdy and masterful he grew, so filled
with bubbling life, so tremulous with the

2387.text:
unspoken wisdom of a life but eighteen months
distant from the All-life,—we were not far

2393.text:
from worshipping this revelation of the divine,
my wife and I. Her own life builded and moulded

2398.text:
itself upon the child; he tinged her every
dream and idealized her every effort.

2405.text:
No hands but hers must touch and garnish those
little limbs; no dress or frill must touch

2410.text:
them that had not wearied her fingers; no
voice but hers could coax him off to Dreamland,

2417.text:
and she and he together spoke some soft and
unknown tongue and in it held communion.

2423.text:
I too mused above his little white bed; saw
the strength of my own arm stretched onward

2429.text:
through the ages through the newer strength
of his; saw the dream of my black fathers

2437.text:
stagger a step onward in the wild phantasm
of the world; heard in his baby voice the

2443.text:
voice of the Prophet that was to rise within
the Veil.

2448.text:
And so we dreamed and loved and planned by
fall and winter, and the full flush of the

2456.text:
long Southern spring, till the hot winds rolled
from the fetid Gulf, till the roses shivered

2462.text:
and the still stern sun quivered its awful
light over the hills of Atlanta.

2467.text:
And then one night the little feet pattered
wearily to the wee white bed, and the tiny

2474.text:
hands trembled; and a warm flushed face tossed
on the pillow, and we knew baby was sick.

2483.text:
Ten days he lay there,—a swift week and
three endless days, wasting, wasting away.

2495.text:
Cheerily the mother nursed him the first days,
and laughed into the little eyes that smiled

2499.text:
again. Tenderly then she hovered round him,
till the smile fled away and Fear crouched

2506.text:
beside the little bed.
Then the day ended not, and night was a dreamless

2514.text:
terror, and joy and sleep slipped away.
I hear now that Voice at midnight calling

2523.text:
me from dull and dreamless trance,—crying,
"The Shadow of Death!

2529.text:
The Shadow of Death!"
Out into the starlight I crept, to rouse the

2534.text:
gray physician,—the Shadow of Death, the
Shadow of Death.

2541.text:
The hours trembled on; the night listened;
the ghastly dawn glided like a tired thing

2547.text:
across the lamplight.
Then we two alone looked upon the child as

2551.text:
he turned toward us with great eyes, and stretched
his stringlike hands,—the Shadow of Death!

2560.text:
And we spoke no word, and turned away.
He died at eventide, when the sun lay like

2572.text:
a brooding sorrow above the western hills,
veiling its face; when the winds spoke not,

2578.text:
and the trees, the great green trees he loved,
stood motionless.

2582.text:
I saw his breath beat quicker and quicker,
pause, and then his little soul leapt like

2590.text:
a star that travels in the night and left
a world of darkness in its train.

2597.text:
The day changed not; the same tall trees peeped
in at the windows, the same green grass glinted

2604.text:
in the setting sun.
Only in the chamber of death writhed the world's

2608.text:
most piteous thing—a childless mother.
I shirk not.

2615.text:
I long for work.
I pant for a life full of striving.

2619.text:
I am no coward, to shrink before the rugged
rush of the storm, nor even quail before the

2624.text:
awful shadow of the Veil.
But hearken, O Death!

2627.text:
Is not this my life hard enough,—is not
that dull land that stretches its sneering

2634.text:
web about me cold enough,—is not all the
world beyond these four little walls pitiless

2639.text:
enough, but that thou must needs enter here,—thou,
O Death?

2644.text:
About my head the thundering storm beat like
a heartless voice, and the crazy forest pulsed

2650.text:
with the curses of the weak; but what cared
I, within my home beside my wife and baby

2658.text:
boy? Wast thou so jealous of one little coign
of happiness that thou must needs enter there,—thou,

2666.text:
O Death?
A perfect life was his, all joy and love,

2675.text:
with tears to make it brighter,—sweet as
a summer's day beside the Housatonic.

2681.text:
The world loved him; the women kissed his
curls, the men looked gravely into his wonderful

2686.text:
eyes, and the children hovered and fluttered
about him.

2690.text:
I can see him now, changing like the sky from
sparkling laughter to darkening frowns, and

2697.text:
then to wondering thoughtfulness as he watched
the world.

2701.text:
He knew no color-line, poor dear—and the
Veil, though it shadowed him, had not yet

2708.text:
darkened half his sun.
He loved the white matron, he loved his black

2713.text:
nurse; and in his little world walked souls
alone, uncolored and unclothed.

2721.text:
I—yea, all men—are larger and purer by
the infinite breadth of that one little life.

2728.text:
She who in simple clearness of vision sees
beyond the stars said when he had flown, "He

2737.text:
will be happy There; he ever loved beautiful
things."

2742.text:
And I, far more ignorant, and blind by the
web of mine own weaving, sit alone winding

2751.text:
words and muttering, "If still he be, and
he be There, and there be a There, let him

2761.text:
be happy, O Fate!"
Blithe was the morning of his burial, with

2766.text:
bird and song and sweet-smelling flowers.
The trees whispered to the grass, but the

2773.text:
children sat with hushed faces.
And yet it seemed a ghostly unreal day,—the

2782.text:
wraith of Life.
We seemed to rumble down an unknown street

2789.text:
behind a little white bundle of posies, with
the shadow of a song in our ears.

2796.text:
The busy city dinned about us; they did not
say much, those pale-faced hurrying men and

2804.text:
women; they did not say much,—they only
glanced and said, "Niggers!"

2812.text:
We could not lay him in the ground there in
Georgia, for the earth there is strangely

2818.text:
red; so we bore him away to the northward,
with his flowers and his little folded hands.

2826.text:
In vain, in vain!—for where, O God!
beneath thy broad blue sky shall my dark baby

2835.text:
rest in peace,—where Reverence dwells, and
Goodness, and a Freedom that is free?

2842.text:
All that day and all that night there sat
an awful gladness in my heart,—nay, blame

2849.text:
me not if I see the world thus darkly through
the Veil,—and my soul whispers ever to me

2856.text:
saying, "Not dead, not dead, but escaped;
not bond, but free."

2866.text:
No bitter meanness now shall sicken his baby
heart till it die a living death, no taunt

2872.text:
shall madden his happy boyhood.
Fool that I was to think or wish that this

2878.text:
little soul should grow choked and deformed
within the Veil!

2882.text:
I might have known that yonder deep unworldly
look that ever and anon floated past his eyes

2889.text:
was peering far beyond this narrow Now.
In the poise of his little curl-crowned head

2896.text:
did there not sit all that wild pride of being
which his father had hardly crushed in his

2901.text:
own heart?
For what, forsooth, shall a Negro want with

2905.text:
pride amid the studied humiliations of fifty
million fellows?

2910.text:
Well sped, my boy, before the world had dubbed
your ambition insolence, had held your ideals

2918.text:
unattainable, and taught you to cringe and
bow.

2923.text:
Better far this nameless void that stops my
life than a sea of sorrow for you.

2932.text:
Idle words; he might have borne his burden
more bravely than we,—aye, and found it

2941.text:
lighter too, some day; for surely, surely
this is not the end.

2952.text:
Surely there shall yet dawn some mighty morning
to lift the Veil and set the prisoned free.

2957.text:
Not for me,—I shall die in my bonds,—but
for fresh young souls who have not known the

2966.text:
night and waken to the morning; a morning
when men ask of the workman, not "Is he white?"

2973.text:
but "Can he work?"
When men ask artists, not "Are they black?"

2980.text:
but "Do they know?"
Some morning this may be, long, long years

2987.text:
to come.
But now there wails, on that dark shore within

2992.text:
the Veil, the same deep voice, THOU SHALT
FOREGO!

2999.text:
And all have I foregone at that command, and
with small complaint,—all save that fair

3008.text:
young form that lies so coldly wed with death
in the nest I had builded.

3015.text:
If one must have gone, why not I?
Why may I not rest me from this restlessness

3025.text:
and sleep from this wide waking?
Was not the world's alembic, Time, in his

3032.text:
young hands, and is not my time waning?
Are there so many workers in the vineyard

3039.text:
that the fair promise of this little body
could lightly be tossed away?

3048.text:
The wretched of my race that line the alleys
of the nation sit fatherless and unmothered;

3054.text:
but Love sat beside his cradle, and in his
ear Wisdom waited to speak.

3063.text:
Perhaps now he knows the All-love, and needs
not to be wise.

3070.text:
Sleep, then, child,—sleep till I sleep and
waken to a baby voice and the ceaseless patter

3081.text:
of little feet—above the Veil.
End of Chapter XI

3097.text:
Then from the Dawn it seemed there came, but
faint

3103.text:
As from beyond the limit of the world,
Like the last echo born of a great cry,

3109.text:
Sounds, as if some fair city were one voice
Around a king returning from his wars.

3148.text:
This is the story of a human heart,—the
tale of a black boy who many long years ago

3154.text:
began to struggle with life that he might
know the world and know himself.

3161.text:
Three temptations he met on those dark dunes
that lay gray and dismal before the wonder-eyes

3166.text:
of the child: the temptation of Hate, that
stood out against the red dawn; the temptation

3173.text:
of Despair, that darkened noonday; and the
temptation of Doubt, that ever steals along

3181.text:
with twilight.
Above all, you must hear of the vales he crossed,—the

3187.text:
Valley of Humiliation and the Valley of the
Shadow of Death.

3192.text:
I saw Alexander Crummell first at a Wilberforce
commencement season, amid its bustle and crush.

3200.text:
Tall, frail, and black he stood, with simple
dignity and an unmistakable air of good breeding.

3207.text:
I talked with him apart, where the storming
of the lusty young orators could not harm

3212.text:
us.
I spoke to him politely, then curiously, then

3217.text:
eagerly, as I began to feel the fineness of
his character,—his calm courtesy, the sweetness

3223.text:
of his strength, and his fair blending of
the hope and truth of life.

3229.text:
Instinctively I bowed before this man, as
one bows before the prophets of the world.

3233.text:
Some seer he seemed, that came not from the
crimson Past or the gray To-come, but from

3240.text:
the pulsing Now,—that mocking world which
seemed to me at once so light and dark, so

3247.text:
splendid and sordid.
Fourscore years had he wandered in this same

3252.text:
world of mine, within the Veil.
He was born with the Missouri Compromise and

3257.text:
lay a-dying amid the echoes of Manila and
El Caney: stirring times for living, times

3263.text:
dark to look back upon, darker to look forward
to. The black-faced lad that paused over his

3270.text:
mud and marbles seventy years ago saw puzzling
vistas as he looked down the world.

3275.text:
The slave-ship still groaned across the Atlantic,
faint cries burdened the Southern breeze,

3281.text:
and the great black father whispered mad tales
of cruelty into those young ears.

3288.text:
From the low doorway the mother silently watched
her boy at play, and at nightfall sought him

3293.text:
eagerly lest the shadows bear him away to
the land of slaves.

3299.text:
So his young mind worked and winced and shaped
curiously a vision of Life; and in the midst

3308.text:
of that vision ever stood one dark figure
alone,—ever with the hard, thick countenance

3313.text:
of that bitter father, and a form that fell
in vast and shapeless folds.

3317.text:
Thus the temptation of Hate grew and shadowed
the growing child,—gliding stealthily into

3324.text:
his laughter, fading into his play, and seizing
his dreams by day and night with rough, rude

3331.text:
turbulence.
So the black boy asked of sky and sun and

3339.text:
flower the never-answered Why? and loved,
as he grew, neither the world nor the world's

3348.text:
rough ways.
Strange temptation for a child, you may think;

3355.text:
and yet in this wide land to-day a thousand
thousand dark children brood before this same

3359.text:
temptation, and feel its cold and shuddering
arms.

3364.text:
For them, perhaps, some one will some day
lift the Veil,—will come tenderly and cheerily

3370.text:
into those sad little lives and brush the
brooding hate away, just as Beriah Green strode

3376.text:
in upon the life of Alexander Crummell.
And before the bluff, kind-hearted man the

3383.text:
shadow seemed less dark.
Beriah Green had a school in Oneida County,

3387.text:
New York, with a score of mischievous boys.
"I'm going to bring a black boy here to educate,"

3393.text:
said Beriah Green, as only a crank and an
abolitionist would have dared to say. "Oho!"

3400.text:
laughed the boys.
"Ye-es," said his wife; and Alexander came.

3407.text:
Once before, the black boy had sought a school,
had travelled, cold and hungry, four hundred

3411.text:
miles up into free New Hampshire, to Canaan.
But the godly farmers hitched ninety yoke

3417.text:
of oxen to the abolition schoolhouse and dragged
it into the middle of the swamp.

3422.text:
The black boy trudged away.
The nineteenth was the first century of human

3429.text:
sympathy,—the age when half wonderingly
we began to descry in others that transfigured

3434.text:
spark of divinity which we call Myself; when
clodhoppers and peasants, and tramps and thieves,

3443.text:
and millionaires and—sometimes—Negroes,
became throbbing souls whose warm pulsing

3447.text:
life touched us so nearly that we half gasped
with surprise, crying, "Thou too!

3452.text:
Hast Thou seen Sorrow and the dull waters
of Hopelessness?

3456.text:
Hast Thou known Life?"
And then all helplessly we peered into those

3460.text:
Other-worlds, and wailed, "O World of Worlds,
how shall man make you one?"

3467.text:
So in that little Oneida school there came
to those schoolboys a revelation of thought

3471.text:
and longing beneath one black skin, of which
they had not dreamed before.

3477.text:
And to the lonely boy came a new dawn of sympathy
and inspiration.

3483.text:
The shadowy, formless thing—the temptation
of Hate, that hovered between him and the

3487.text:
world—grew fainter and less sinister.
It did not wholly fade away, but diffused

3494.text:
itself and lingered thick at the edges.
Through it the child now first saw the blue

3499.text:
and gold of life,—the sun-swept road that
ran 'twixt heaven and earth until in one far-off

3505.text:
wan wavering line they met and kissed.
A vision of life came to the growing boy,—mystic,

3512.text:
wonderful.
He raised his head, stretched himself, breathed

3517.text:
deep of the fresh new air. Yonder, behind
the forests, he heard strange sounds; then

3524.text:
glinting through the trees he saw, far, far
away, the bronzed hosts of a nation calling,—calling

3529.text:
faintly, calling loudly.
He heard the hateful clank of their chains;

3535.text:
he felt them cringe and grovel, and there
rose within him a protest and a prophecy.

3541.text:
And he girded himself to walk down the world.
A voice and vision called him to be a priest,—a

3551.text:
seer to lead the uncalled out of the house
of bondage.

3555.text:
He saw the headless host turn toward him like
the whirling of mad waters,—he stretched

3560.text:
forth his hands eagerly, and then, even as
he stretched them, suddenly there swept across

3566.text:
the vision the temptation of Despair.
They were not wicked men,—the problem of

3572.text:
life is not the problem of the wicked,—they
were calm, good men, Bishops of the Apostolic

3579.text:
Church of God, and strove toward righteousness.
They said slowly, "It is all very natural—it

3587.text:
is even commendable; but the General Theological
Seminary of the Episcopal Church cannot admit

3593.text:
a Negro."
And when that thin, half-grotesque figure

3597.text:
still haunted their doors, they put their
hands kindly, half sorrowfully, on his shoulders,

3604.text:
and said, "Now,—of course, we—we know
how YOU feel about it; but you see it is impossible,—that

3610.text:
is—well—it is premature.
Sometime, we trust—sincerely trust—all

3615.text:
such distinctions will fade away; but now
the world is as it is."

3620.text:
This was the temptation of Despair; and the
young man fought it doggedly.

3626.text:
Like some grave shadow he flitted by those
halls, pleading, arguing, half angrily demanding

3631.text:
admittance, until there came the final NO:
until men hustled the disturber away, marked

3639.text:
him as foolish, unreasonable, and injudicious,
a vain rebel against God's law.

3647.text:
And then from that Vision Splendid all the
glory faded slowly away, and left an earth

3655.text:
gray and stern rolling on beneath a dark despair.
Even the kind hands that stretched themselves

3662.text:
toward him from out the depths of that dull
morning seemed but parts of the purple shadows.

3669.text:
He saw them coldly, and asked, "Why should
I strive by special grace when the way of

3675.text:
the world is closed to me?"
All gently yet, the hands urged him on,—the

3683.text:
hands of young John Jay, that daring father's
daring son; the hands of the good folk of

3690.text:
Boston, that free city.
And yet, with a way to the priesthood of the

3695.text:
Church open at last before him, the cloud
lingered there; and even when in old St. Paul's

3703.text:
the venerable Bishop raised his white arms
above the Negro deacon—even then the burden

3708.text:
had not lifted from that heart, for there
had passed a glory from the earth.

3715.text:
And yet the fire through which Alexander Crummell
went did not burn in vain.

3721.text:
Slowly and more soberly he took up again his
plan of life.

3725.text:
More critically he studied the situation.
Deep down below the slavery and servitude

3731.text:
of the Negro people he saw their fatal weaknesses,
which long years of mistreatment had emphasized.

3738.text:
The dearth of strong moral character, of unbending
righteousness, he felt, was their great shortcoming,

3746.text:
and here he would begin.
He would gather the best of his people into

3750.text:
some little Episcopal chapel and there lead,
teach, and inspire them, till the leaven spread,

3758.text:
till the children grew, till the world hearkened,
till—till—and then across his dream gleamed

3766.text:
some faint after-glow of that first fair vision
of youth—only an after-glow, for there had

3773.text:
passed a glory from the earth.
One day—it was in 1842, and the springtide

3781.text:
was struggling merrily with the May winds
of New England—he stood at last in his own

3785.text:
chapel in Providence, a priest of the Church.
The days sped by, and the dark young clergyman

3793.text:
labored; he wrote his sermons carefully; he
intoned his prayers with a soft, earnest voice;

3800.text:
he haunted the streets and accosted the wayfarers;
he visited the sick, and knelt beside the

3805.text:
dying.
He worked and toiled, week by week, day by

3810.text:
day, month by month.
And yet month by month the congregation dwindled,

3817.text:
week by week the hollow walls echoed more
sharply, day by day the calls came fewer and

3822.text:
fewer, and day by day the third temptation
sat clearer and still more clearly within

3829.text:
the Veil; a temptation, as it were, bland
and smiling, with just a shade of mockery

3835.text:
in its smooth tones.
First it came casually, in the cadence of

3843.text:
Or perhaps more definitely: "What do you EXPECT?"
In voice and gesture lay the doubt—the temptation

3853.text:
of Doubt.
How he hated it, and stormed at it furiously!

3858.text:
"Of course they are capable," he cried; "of
course they can learn and strive and achieve—"

3865.text:
and "Of course," added the temptation softly,
"they do nothing of the sort."

3874.text:
Of all the three temptations, this one struck
the deepest.

3879.text:
Hate?
He had outgrown so childish a thing.

3883.text:
Despair?
He had steeled his right arm against it, and

3885.text:
fought it with the vigor of determination.
But to doubt the worth of his life-work,—to

3892.text:
doubt the destiny and capability of the race
his soul loved because it was his; to find

3899.text:
listless squalor instead of eager endeavor;
to hear his own lips whispering, "They do

3905.text:
not care; they cannot know; they are dumb
driven cattle,—why cast your pearls before

3911.text:
swine?"—this, this seemed more than man
could bear; and he closed the door, and sank

3918.text:
upon the steps of the chancel, and cast his
robe upon the floor and writhed.

3925.text:
The evening sunbeams had set the dust to dancing
in the gloomy chapel when he arose.

3930.text:
He folded his vestments, put away the hymn-books,
and closed the great Bible.

3936.text:
He stepped out into the twilight, looked back
upon the narrow little pulpit with a weary

3940.text:
smile, and locked the door. Then he walked
briskly to the Bishop, and told the Bishop

3946.text:
what the Bishop already knew.
"I have failed," he said simply.

3954.text:
And gaining courage by the confession, he
added: "What I need is a larger constituency.

3959.text:
There are comparatively few Negroes here,
and perhaps they are not of the best.

3965.text:
I must go where the field is wider, and try
again."

3969.text:
So the Bishop sent him to Philadelphia, with
a letter to Bishop Onderdonk.

3976.text:
Bishop Onderdonk lived at the head of six
white steps,—corpulent, red-faced, and the

3980.text:
author of several thrilling tracts on Apostolic
Succession.

3986.text:
It was after dinner, and the Bishop had settled
himself for a pleasant season of contemplation,

3991.text:
when the bell must needs ring, and there must
burst in upon the Bishop a letter and a thin,

3999.text:
ungainly Negro.
Bishop Onderdonk read the letter hastily and

4003.text:
frowned. Fortunately, his mind was already
clear on this point; and he cleared his brow

4008.text:
and looked at Crummell.
Then he said, slowly and impressively: "I

4013.text:
will receive you into this diocese on one
condition: no Negro priest can sit in my church

4020.text:
convention, and no Negro church must ask for
representation there."

4026.text:
I sometimes fancy I can see that tableau:
the frail black figure, nervously twitching

4033.text:
his hat before the massive abdomen of Bishop
Onderdonk; his threadbare coat thrown against

4038.text:
the dark woodwork of the bookcases, where
Fox's "Lives of the Martyrs" nestled happily

4044.text:
beside "The Whole Duty of Man."
I seem to see the wide eyes of the Negro wander

4050.text:
past the Bishop's broadcloth to where the
swinging glass doors of the cabinet glow in

4055.text:
the sunlight.
A little blue fly is trying to cross the yawning

4058.text:
keyhole.
He marches briskly up to it, peers into the

4062.text:
chasm in a surprised sort of way, and rubs
his feelers reflectively; then he essays its

4069.text:
depths, and, finding it bottomless, draws
back again.

4073.text:
The dark-faced priest finds himself wondering
if the fly too has faced its Valley of Humiliation,

4080.text:
and if it will plunge into it,—when lo!
it spreads its tiny wings and buzzes merrily

4086.text:
across, leaving the watcher wingless and alone.
Then the full weight of his burden fell upon

4094.text:
him.
The rich walls wheeled away, and before him

4099.text:
lay the cold rough moor winding on through
life, cut in twain by one thick granite ridge,—here,

4107.text:
the Valley of Humiliation; yonder, the Valley
of the Shadow of Death.

4113.text:
And I know not which be darker,—no, not
I. But this I know: in yonder Vale of the

4122.text:
Humble stand to-day a million swarthy men,
who willingly would

4126.text:
". . . bear the whips and scorns of time,
The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,

4133.text:
The pangs of despised love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office, and the spurns

4138.text:
That patient merit of the unworthy takes,"—
all this and more would they bear did they

4144.text:
but know that this were sacrifice and not
a meaner thing.

4150.text:
So surged the thought within that lone black
breast.

4154.text:
The Bishop cleared his throat suggestively;
then, recollecting that there was really nothing

4159.text:
to say, considerately said nothing, only sat
tapping his foot impatiently.

4166.text:
But Alexander Crummell said, slowly and heavily:
"I will never enter your diocese on such terms."

4177.text:
And saying this, he turned and passed into
the Valley of the Shadow of Death.

4185.text:
You might have noted only the physical dying,
the shattered frame and hacking cough; but

4192.text:
in that soul lay deeper death than that.
He found a chapel in New York,—the church

4199.text:
of his father; he labored for it in poverty
and starvation, scorned by his fellow priests.

4206.text:
Half in despair, he wandered across the sea,
a beggar with outstretched hands.

4212.text:
Englishmen clasped them,—Wilberforce and
Stanley, Thirwell and Ingles, and even Froude

4219.text:
and Macaulay; Sir Benjamin Brodie bade him
rest awhile at Queen's College in Cambridge,

4224.text:
and there he lingered, struggling for health
of body and mind, until he took his degree

4230.text:
in '53.
Restless still, and unsatisfied, he turned

4236.text:
toward Africa, and for long years, amid the
spawn of the slave-smugglers, sought a new

4241.text:
heaven and a new earth.
So the man groped for light; all this was

4247.text:
not Life,—it was the world-wandering of
a soul in search of itself, the striving of

4253.text:
one who vainly sought his place in the world,
ever haunted by the shadow of a death that

4258.text:
is more than death,—the passing of a soul
that has missed its duty.

4266.text:
Twenty years he wandered,—twenty years and
more; and yet the hard rasping question kept

4272.text:
gnawing within him, "What, in God's name,
am I on earth for?"

4279.text:
In the narrow New York parish his soul seemed
cramped and smothered.

4283.text:
In the fine old air of the English University
he heard the millions wailing over the sea.

4289.text:
In the wild fever-cursed swamps of West Africa
he stood helpless and alone.

4296.text:
You will not wonder at his weird pilgrimage,—you
who in the swift whirl of living, amid its

4301.text:
cold paradox and marvellous vision, have fronted
life and asked its riddle face to face.

4308.text:
And if you find that riddle hard to read,
remember that yonder black boy finds it just

4313.text:
a little harder; if it is difficult for you
to find and face your duty, it is a shade

4319.text:
more difficult for him; if your heart sickens
in the blood and dust of battle, remember

4325.text:
that to him the dust is thicker and the battle
fiercer.

4329.text:
No wonder the wanderers fall!
No wonder we point to thief and murderer,

4334.text:
and haunting prostitute, and the never-ending
throng of unhearsed dead!

4340.text:
The Valley of the Shadow of Death gives few
of its pilgrims back to the world.

4345.text:
But Alexander Crummell it gave back.
Out of the temptation of Hate, and burned

4352.text:
by the fire of Despair, triumphant over Doubt,
and steeled by Sacrifice against Humiliation,

4359.text:
he turned at last home across the waters,
humble and strong, gentle and determined.

4367.text:
He bent to all the gibes and prejudices, to
all hatred and discrimination, with that rare

4372.text:
courtesy which is the armor of pure souls.
He fought among his own, the low, the grasping,

4380.text:
and the wicked, with that unbending righteousness
which is the sword of the just.

4385.text:
He never faltered, he seldom complained; he
simply worked, inspiring the young, rebuking

4393.text:
the old, helping the weak, guiding the strong.
So he grew, and brought within his wide influence

4401.text:
all that was best of those who walk within
the Veil.

4405.text:
They who live without knew not nor dreamed
of that full power within, that mighty inspiration

4411.text:
which the dull gauze of caste decreed that
most men should not know.

4417.text:
And now that he is gone, I sweep the Veil
away and cry, Lo! the soul to whose dear memory

4424.text:
I bring this little tribute.
I can see his face still, dark and heavy-lined

4432.text:
beneath his snowy hair; lighting and shading,
now with inspiration for the future, now in

4439.text:
innocent pain at some human wickedness, now
with sorrow at some hard memory from the past.

4446.text:
The more I met Alexander Crummell, the more
I felt how much that world was losing which

4451.text:
knew so little of him.
In another age he might have sat among the

4456.text:
elders of the land in purple-bordered toga;
in another country mothers might have sung

4463.text:
him to the cradles.
He did his work,—he did it nobly and well;

4470.text:
and yet I sorrow that here he worked alone,
with so little human sympathy.

4476.text:
His name to-day, in this broad land, means
little, and comes to fifty million ears laden

4481.text:
with no incense of memory or emulation.
And herein lies the tragedy of the age: not

4489.text:
that men are poor,—all men know something
of poverty; not that men are wicked,—who

4495.text:
is good? not that men are ignorant,—what
is Truth?

4501.text:
Nay, but that men know so little of men.
He sat one morning gazing toward the sea.

4512.text:
He smiled and said, "The gate is rusty on
the hinges."

4517.text:
That night at starrise a wind came moaning
out of the west to blow the gate ajar, and

4524.text:
then the soul I loved fled like a flame across
the Seas, and in its seat sat Death.

4532.text:
I wonder where he is to-day?
I wonder if in that dim world beyond, as he

4541.text:
came gliding in, there rose on some wan throne
a King,—a dark and pierced Jew, who knows

4550.text:
the writhings of the earthly damned, saying,
as he laid those heart-wrung talents down,

4557.text:
"Well done!" while round about the morning
stars sat singing.

4566.text:
End of Chapter XII
Chapter XIII

4577.text:
Beside the River-sea?
They bring the human heart wherein

4580.text:
No nightly calm can be;
That droppeth never with the wind,

4584.text:
Nor drieth with the dew;
O calm it, God; thy calm is broad

4612.text:
Carlisle Street runs westward from the centre
of Johnstown, across a great black bridge,

4617.text:
down a hill and up again, by little shops
and meat-markets, past single-storied homes,

4623.text:
until suddenly it stops against a wide green
lawn.

4626.text:
It is a broad, restful place, with two large
buildings outlined against the west.

4634.text:
When at evening the winds come swelling from
the east, and the great pall of the city's

4638.text:
smoke hangs wearily above the valley, then
the red west glows like a dreamland down Carlisle

4643.text:
Street, and, at the tolling of the supper-bell,
throws the passing forms of students in dark

4648.text:
silhouette against the sky.
Tall and black, they move slowly by, and seem

4653.text:
in the sinister light to flit before the city
like dim warning ghosts.

4658.text:
Perhaps they are; for this is Wells Institute,
and these black students have few dealings

4662.text:
with the white city below.
And if you will notice, night after night,

4666.text:
there is one dark form that ever hurries last
and late toward the twinkling lights of Swain

4671.text:
Hall,—for Jones is never on time.
A long, straggling fellow he is, brown and

4677.text:
hard-haired, who seems to be growing straight
out of his clothes, and walks with a half-apologetic

4682.text:
roll.
He used perpetually to set the quiet dining-room

4685.text:
into waves of merriment, as he stole to his
place after the bell had tapped for prayers;

4689.text:
he seemed so perfectly awkward.
And yet one glance at his face made one forgive

4694.text:
him much,—that broad, good-natured smile
in which lay no bit of art or artifice, but

4700.text:
seemed just bubbling good-nature and genuine
satisfaction with the world.

4705.text:
He came to us from Altamaha, away down there
beneath the gnarled oaks of Southeastern Georgia,

4710.text:
where the sea croons to the sands and the
sands listen till they sink half drowned beneath

4715.text:
the waters, rising only here and there in
long, low islands.

4721.text:
The white folk of Altamaha voted John a good
boy,—fine plough-hand, good in the rice-fields,

4726.text:
handy everywhere, and always good-natured
and respectful.

4730.text:
But they shook their heads when his mother
wanted to send him off to school. "It'll spoil

4735.text:
him,—ruin him," they said; and they talked
as though they knew.

4739.text:
But full half the black folk followed him
proudly to the station, and carried his queer

4744.text:
little trunk and many bundles.
And there they shook and shook hands, and

4749.text:
the girls kissed him shyly and the boys clapped
him on the back.

4753.text:
So the train came, and he pinched his little
sister lovingly, and put his great arms about

4757.text:
his mother's neck, and then was away with
a puff and a roar into the great yellow world

4762.text:
that flamed and flared about the doubtful
pilgrim.

4766.text:
Up the coast they hurried, past the squares
and palmettos of Savannah, through the cotton-fields

4771.text:
and through the weary night, to Millville,
and came with the morning to the noise and

4776.text:
bustle of Johnstown.
And they that stood behind, that morning in

4781.text:
Altamaha, and watched the train as it noisily
bore playmate and brother and son away to

4785.text:
the world, had thereafter one ever-recurring
word,—"When John comes." Then what parties

4793.text:
were to be, and what speakings in the churches;
what new furniture in the front room,—perhaps

4799.text:
even a new front room; and there would be
a new schoolhouse, with John as teacher; and

4805.text:
then perhaps a big wedding; all this and more—when
John comes.

4811.text:
But the white people shook their heads.
At first he was coming at Christmas-time,—but

4817.text:
the vacation proved too short; and then, the
next summer,—but times were hard and schooling

4824.text:
costly, and so, instead, he worked in Johnstown.
And so it drifted to the next summer, and

4831.text:
the next,—till playmates scattered, and
mother grew gray, and sister went up to the

4837.text:
Judge's kitchen to work.
And still the legend lingered,—"When John

4842.text:
comes."
Up at the Judge's they rather liked this refrain;

4847.text:
for they too had a John—a fair-haired, smooth-faced
boy, who had played many a long summer's day

4853.text:
to its close with his darker namesake.
"Yes, sir!

4857.text:
John is at Princeton, sir," said the broad-shouldered
gray-haired Judge every morning as he marched

4862.text:
down to the post-office.
"Showing the Yankees what a Southern gentleman

4865.text:
can do," he added; and strode home again with
his letters and papers.

4869.text:
Up at the great pillared house they lingered
long over the Princeton letter,—the Judge

4874.text:
and his frail wife, his sister and growing
daughters.

4877.text:
"It'll make a man of him," said the Judge,
"college is the place."

4883.text:
And then he asked the shy little waitress,
"Well, Jennie, how's your John?" and added

4888.text:
reflectively, "Too bad, too bad your mother
sent him off—it will spoil him."

4893.text:
And the waitress wondered.
Thus in the far-away Southern village the

4897.text:
world lay waiting, half consciously, the coming
of two young men, and dreamed in an inarticulate

4903.text:
way of new things that would be done and new
thoughts that all would think.

4907.text:
And yet it was singular that few thought of
two Johns,—for the black folk thought of

4912.text:
one John, and he was black; and the white
folk thought of another John, and he was white.

4916.text:
And neither world thought the other world's
thought, save with a vague unrest.

4921.text:
Up in Johnstown, at the Institute, we were
long puzzled at the case of John Jones.

4927.text:
For a long time the clay seemed unfit for
any sort of moulding.

4931.text:
He was loud and boisterous, always laughing
and singing, and never able to work consecutively

4936.text:
at anything.
He did not know how to study; he had no idea

4940.text:
of thoroughness; and with his tardiness, carelessness,
and appalling good-humor, we were sore perplexed.

4947.text:
One night we sat in faculty-meeting, worried
and serious; for Jones was in trouble again.

4952.text:
This last escapade was too much, and so we
solemnly voted "that Jones, on account of

4957.text:
repeated disorder and inattention to work,
be suspended for the rest of the term."

4963.text:
It seemed to us that the first time life ever
struck Jones as a really serious thing was

4967.text:
when the Dean told him he must leave school.
He stared at the gray-haired man blankly,

4972.text:
with great eyes.
"Why,—why," he faltered, "but—I haven't

4981.text:
graduated!"
Then the Dean slowly and clearly explained,

4984.text:
reminding him of the tardiness and the carelessness,
of the poor lessons and neglected work, of

4989.text:
the noise and disorder, until the fellow hung
his head in confusion.

4994.text:
Then he said quickly, "But you won't tell
mammy and sister,—you won't write mammy,

4998.text:
now will you?
For if you won't I'll go out into the city

5001.text:
and work, and come back next term and show
you something."

5006.text:
So the Dean promised faithfully, and John
shouldered his little trunk, giving neither

5011.text:
word nor look to the giggling boys, and walked
down Carlisle Street to the great city, with

5017.text:
sober eyes and a set and serious face.
Perhaps we imagined it, but someway it seemed

5023.text:
to us that the serious look that crept over
his boyish face that afternoon never left

5027.text:
it again.
When he came back to us he went to work with

5030.text:
all his rugged strength.
It was a hard struggle, for things did not

5034.text:
come easily to him,—few crowding memories
of early life and teaching came to help him

5039.text:
on his new way; but all the world toward which
he strove was of his own building, and he

5044.text:
builded slow and hard.
As the light dawned lingeringly on his new

5048.text:
creations, he sat rapt and silent before the
vision, or wandered alone over the green campus

5054.text:
peering through and beyond the world of men
into a world of thought.

5058.text:
And the thoughts at times puzzled him sorely;
he could not see just why the circle was not

5063.text:
square, and carried it out fifty-six decimal
places one midnight,—would have gone further,

5067.text:
indeed, had not the matron rapped for lights
out.

5071.text:
He caught terrible colds lying on his back
in the meadows of nights, trying to think

5075.text:
out the solar system; he had grave doubts
as to the ethics of the Fall of Rome, and

5081.text:
strongly suspected the Germans of being thieves
and rascals, despite his textbooks; he pondered

5086.text:
long over every new Greek word, and wondered
why this meant that and why it couldn't mean

5092.text:
something else, and how it must have felt
to think all things in Greek.

5096.text:
So he thought and puzzled along for himself,—pausing
perplexed where others skipped merrily, and

5103.text:
walking steadily through the difficulties
where the rest stopped and surrendered.

5107.text:
Thus he grew in body and soul, and with him
his clothes seemed to grow and arrange themselves;

5112.text:
coat sleeves got longer, cuffs appeared, and
collars got less soiled.

5117.text:
Now and then his boots shone, and a new dignity
crept into his walk.

5122.text:
And we who saw daily a new thoughtfulness
growing in his eyes began to expect something

5126.text:
of this plodding boy. Thus he passed out of
the preparatory school into college, and we

5132.text:
who watched him felt four more years of change,
which almost transformed the tall, grave man

5138.text:
who bowed to us commencement morning.
He had left his queer thought-world and come

5142.text:
back to a world of motion and of men. He looked
now for the first time sharply about him,

5148.text:
and wondered he had seen so little before.
He grew slowly to feel almost for the first

5153.text:
time the Veil that lay between him and the
white world; he first noticed now the oppression

5159.text:
that had not seemed oppression before, differences
that erstwhile seemed natural, restraints

5165.text:
and slights that in his boyhood days had gone
unnoticed or been greeted with a laugh. He

5170.text:
felt angry now when men did not call him "Mister,"
he clenched his hands at the "Jim Crow" cars,

5176.text:
and chafed at the color-line that hemmed in
him and his.

5180.text:
A tinge of sarcasm crept into his speech,
and a vague bitterness into his life; and

5186.text:
he sat long hours wondering and planning a
way around these crooked things.

5191.text:
Daily he found himself shrinking from the
choked and narrow life of his native town.

5196.text:
And yet he always planned to go back to Altamaha,—always
planned to work there.

5201.text:
Still, more and more as the day approached
he hesitated with a nameless dread; and even

5207.text:
the day after graduation he seized with eagerness
the offer of the Dean to send him North with

5211.text:
the quartette during the summer vacation,
to sing for the Institute.

5215.text:
A breath of air before the plunge, he said
to himself in half apology.

5221.text:
It was a bright September afternoon, and the
streets of New York were brilliant with moving

5226.text:
men.
They reminded John of the sea, as he sat in

5229.text:
the square and watched them, so changelessly
changing, so bright and dark, so grave and

5235.text:
gay.
He scanned their rich and faultless clothes,

5238.text:
the way they carried their hands, the shape
of their hats; he peered into the hurrying

5243.text:
carriages.
Then, leaning back with a sigh, he said, "This

5248.text:
is the World."
The notion suddenly seized him to see where

5252.text:
the world was going; since many of the richer
and brighter seemed hurrying all one way.

5258.text:
So when a tall, light-haired young man and
a little talkative lady came by, he rose half

5263.text:
hesitatingly and followed them. Up the street
they went, past stores and gay shops, across

5269.text:
a broad square, until with a hundred others
they entered the high portal of a great building.

5275.text:
He was pushed toward the ticket-office with
the others, and felt in his pocket for the

5278.text:
new five-dollar bill he had hoarded.
There seemed really no time for hesitation,

5283.text:
so he drew it bravely out, passed it to the
busy clerk, and received simply a ticket but

5289.text:
no change.
When at last he realized that he had paid

5293.text:
five dollars to enter he knew not what, he
stood stockstill amazed.

5298.text:
"Be careful," said a low voice behind him;
"you must not lynch the colored gentleman

5304.text:
simply because he's in your way," and a girl
looked up roguishly into the eyes of her fair-haired

5311.text:
escort.
A shade of annoyance passed over the escort's

5313.text:
face.
"You WILL not understand us at the South,"

5318.text:
he said half impatiently, as if continuing
an argument.

5321.text:
"With all your professions, one never sees
in the North so cordial and intimate relations

5326.text:
between white and black as are everyday occurrences
with us.

5330.text:
Why, I remember my closest playfellow in boyhood
was a little Negro named after me, and surely

5338.text:
no two,—WELL!" The man stopped short and
flushed to the roots of his hair, for there

5345.text:
directly beside his reserved orchestra chairs
sat the Negro he had stumbled over in the

5349.text:
hallway.
He hesitated and grew pale with anger, called

5354.text:
the usher and gave him his card, with a few
peremptory words, and slowly sat down.

5359.text:
The lady deftly changed the subject.
All this John did not see, for he sat in a

5366.text:
half-daze minding the scene about him; the
