delicate beauty of the hall, the faint perfume,

5373.text:
the moving myriad of men, the rich clothing
and low hum of talking seemed all a part of

5378.text:
a world so different from his, so strangely
more beautiful than anything he had known,

5383.text:
that he sat in dreamland, and started when,
after a hush, rose high and clear the music

5389.text:
of Lohengrin's swan.
The infinite beauty of the wail lingered and

5393.text:
swept through every muscle of his frame, and
put it all a-tune.

5397.text:
He closed his eyes and grasped the elbows
of the chair, touching unwittingly the lady's

5401.text:
arm.
And the lady drew away.

5404.text:
A deep longing swelled in all his heart to
rise with that clear music out of the dirt

5409.text:
and dust of that low life that held him prisoned
and befouled.

5412.text:
If he could only live up in the free air where
birds sang and setting suns had no touch of

5419.text:
blood!
Who had called him to be the slave and butt

5423.text:
of all?
And if he had called, what right had he to

5425.text:
call when a world like this lay open before
men?

5430.text:
Then the movement changed, and fuller, mightier
harmony swelled away. He looked thoughtfully

5436.text:
across the hall, and wondered why the beautiful
gray-haired woman looked so listless, and

5441.text:
what the little man could be whispering about.
He would not like to be listless and idle,

5446.text:
he thought, for he felt with the music the
movement of power within him. If he but had

5451.text:
some master-work, some life-service, hard,—aye,
bitter hard, but without the cringing and

5457.text:
sickening servility, without the cruel hurt
that hardened his heart and soul.

5462.text:
When at last a soft sorrow crept across the
violins, there came to him the vision of a

5467.text:
far-off home, the great eyes of his sister,
and the dark drawn face of his mother.

5472.text:
And his heart sank below the waters, even
as the sea-sand sinks by the shores of Altamaha,

5479.text:
only to be lifted aloft again with that last
ethereal wail of the swan that quivered and

5484.text:
faded away into the sky.
It left John sitting so silent and rapt that

5489.text:
he did not for some time notice the usher
tapping him lightly on the shoulder and saying

5494.text:
politely, "Will you step this way, please,
sir?"

5497.text:
A little surprised, he arose quickly at the
last tap, and, turning to leave his seat,

5503.text:
looked full into the face of the fair-haired
young man.

5505.text:
For the first time the young man recognized
his dark boyhood playmate, and John knew that

5511.text:
it was the Judge's son.
The White John started, lifted his hand, and

5517.text:
then froze into his chair; the black John
smiled lightly, then grimly, and followed

5525.text:
the usher down the aisle.
The manager was sorry, very, very sorry,—but

5530.text:
he explained that some mistake had been made
in selling the gentleman a seat already disposed

5534.text:
of; he would refund the money, of course,—and
indeed felt the matter keenly, and so forth,

5540.text:
and—before he had finished John was gone,
walking hurriedly across the square and down

5545.text:
the broad streets, and as he passed the park
he buttoned his coat and said, "John Jones,

5550.text:
you're a natural-born fool." Then he went
to his lodgings and wrote a letter, and tore

5557.text:
it up; he wrote another, and threw it in the
fire.

5561.text:
Then he seized a scrap of paper and wrote:
"Dear Mother and Sister—I am coming—John."

5570.text:
"Perhaps," said John, as he settled himself
on the train, "perhaps I am to blame myself

5578.text:
in struggling against my manifest destiny
simply because it looks hard and unpleasant.

5582.text:
Here is my duty to Altamaha plain before me;
perhaps they'll let me help settle the Negro

5587.text:
problems there,—perhaps they won't.
'I will go in to the King, which is not according

5592.text:
to the law; and if I perish, I perish.'" And
then he mused and dreamed, and planned a life-work;

5599.text:
and the train flew south.
Down in Altamaha, after seven long years,

5606.text:
all the world knew John was coming.
The homes were scrubbed and scoured,—above

5610.text:
all, one; the gardens and yards had an unwonted
trimness, and Jennie bought a new gingham.

5617.text:
With some finesse and negotiation, all the
dark Methodists and Presbyterians were induced

5621.text:
to join in a monster welcome at the Baptist
Church; and as the day drew near, warm discussions

5627.text:
arose on every corner as to the exact extent
and nature of John's accomplishments.

5633.text:
It was noontide on a gray and cloudy day when
he came.

5636.text:
The black town flocked to the depot, with
a little of the white at the edges,—a happy

5643.text:
throng, with "Good-mawnings" and "Howdys"
and laughing and joking and jostling.

5650.text:
Mother sat yonder in the window watching;
but sister Jennie stood on the platform, nervously

5655.text:
fingering her dress, tall and lithe, with
soft brown skin and loving eyes peering from

5662.text:
out a tangled wilderness of hair.
John rose gloomily as the train stopped, for

5667.text:
he was thinking of the "Jim Crow" car; he
stepped to the platform, and paused: a little

5673.text:
dingy station, a black crowd gaudy and dirty,
a half-mile of dilapidated shanties along

5679.text:
a straggling ditch of mud.
An overwhelming sense of the sordidness and

5684.text:
narrowness of it all seized him; he looked
in vain for his mother, kissed coldly the

5689.text:
tall, strange girl who called him brother,
spoke a short, dry word here and there; then,

5695.text:
lingering neither for handshaking nor gossip,
started silently up the street, raising his

5701.text:
hat merely to the last eager old aunty, to
her open-mouthed astonishment.

5706.text:
The people were distinctly bewildered.
This silent, cold man,—was this John?

5712.text:
Where was his smile and hearty hand-grasp?
"'Peared kind o' down in the mouf," said the

5718.text:
Methodist preacher thoughtfully.
"Seemed monstus stuck up," complained a Baptist

5723.text:
sister.
But the white postmaster from the edge of

5729.text:
the crowd expressed the opinion of his folks
plainly.

5733.text:
"That damn Nigger," said he, as he shouldered
the mail and arranged his tobacco, "has gone

5736.text:
North and got plum full o' fool notions; but
they won't work in Altamaha."

5743.text:
And the crowd melted away.
The meeting of welcome at the Baptist Church

5747.text:
was a failure.
Rain spoiled the barbecue, and thunder turned

5752.text:
the milk in the ice-cream. When the speaking
came at night, the house was crowded to overflowing.

5758.text:
The three preachers had especially prepared
themselves, but somehow John's manner seemed

5762.text:
to throw a blanket over everything,—he seemed
so cold and preoccupied, and had so strange

5767.text:
an air of restraint that the Methodist brother
could not warm up to his theme and elicited

5772.text:
not a single "Amen"; the Presbyterian prayer
was but feebly responded to, and even the

5778.text:
Baptist preacher, though he wakened faint
enthusiasm, got so mixed up in his favorite

5782.text:
sentence that he had to close it by stopping
fully fifteen minutes sooner than he meant.

5787.text:
The people moved uneasily in their seats as
John rose to reply.

5791.text:
He spoke slowly and methodically.
The age, he said, demanded new ideas; we were

5798.text:
far different from those men of the seventeenth
and eighteenth centuries,—with broader ideas

5803.text:
of human brotherhood and destiny.
Then he spoke of the rise of charity and popular

5808.text:
education, and particularly of the spread
of wealth and work.

5812.text:
The question was, then, he added reflectively,
looking at the low discolored ceiling, what

5818.text:
part the Negroes of this land would take in
the striving of the new century.

5823.text:
He sketched in vague outline the new Industrial
School that might rise among these pines,

5828.text:
he spoke in detail of the charitable and philanthropic
work that might be organized, of money that

5832.text:
might be saved for banks and business.
Finally he urged unity, and deprecated especially

5839.text:
religious and denominational bickering.
"To-day," he said, with a smile, "the world

5845.text:
cares little whether a man be Baptist or Methodist,
or indeed a churchman at all, so long as he

5851.text:
is good and true.
What difference does it make whether a man

5854.text:
be baptized in river or washbowl, or not at
all?

5859.text:
Let's leave all that littleness, and look
higher."

5862.text:
Then, thinking of nothing else, he slowly
sat down.

5867.text:
A painful hush seized that crowded mass.
Little had they understood of what he said,

5872.text:
for he spoke an unknown tongue, save the last
word about baptism; that they knew, and they

5879.text:
sat very still while the clock ticked.
Then at last a low suppressed snarl came from

5886.text:
the Amen corner, and an old bent man arose,
walked over the seats, and climbed straight

5891.text:
up into the pulpit.
He was wrinkled and black, with scant gray

5895.text:
and tufted hair; his voice and hands shook
as with palsy; but on his face lay the intense

5902.text:
rapt look of the religious fanatic.
He seized the Bible with his rough, huge hands;

5907.text:
twice he raised it inarticulate, and then
fairly burst into words, with rude and awful

5916.text:
eloquence.
He quivered, swayed, and bent; then rose aloft

5920.text:
in perfect majesty, till the people moaned
and wept, wailed and shouted, and a wild shrieking

5926.text:
arose from the corners where all the pent-up
feeling of the hour gathered itself and rushed

5930.text:
into the air.
John never knew clearly what the old man said;

5935.text:
he only felt himself held up to scorn and
scathing denunciation for trampling on the

5939.text:
true Religion, and he realized with amazement
that all unknowingly he had put rough, rude

5945.text:
hands on something this little world held
sacred.

5948.text:
He arose silently, and passed out into the
night.

5952.text:
Down toward the sea he went, in the fitful
starlight, half conscious of the girl who

5958.text:
followed timidly after him. When at last he
stood upon the bluff, he turned to his little

5963.text:
sister and looked upon her sorrowfully, remembering
with sudden pain how little thought he had

5968.text:
given her.
He put his arm about her and let her passion

5970.text:
of tears spend itself on his shoulder.
Long they stood together, peering over the

5976.text:
gray unresting water.
"John," she said, "does it make every one—unhappy

5984.text:
when they study and learn lots of things?"
He paused and smiled.

5990.text:
"I am afraid it does," he said.
"And, John, are you glad you studied?"

6000.text:
"Yes," came the answer, slowly but positively.
She watched the flickering lights upon the

6010.text:
sea, and said thoughtfully, "I wish I was
unhappy,—and—and," putting both arms about

6019.text:
his neck, "I think I am, a little, John."
It was several days later that John walked

6027.text:
up to the Judge's house to ask for the privilege
of teaching the Negro school.

6031.text:
The Judge himself met him at the front door,
stared a little hard at him, and said brusquely,

6037.text:
"Go 'round to the kitchen door, John, and
wait."

6038.text:
Sitting on the kitchen steps, John stared
at the corn, thoroughly perplexed.

6044.text:
What on earth had come over him?
Every step he made offended some one.

6051.text:
He had come to save his people, and before
he left the depot he had hurt them.

6056.text:
He sought to teach them at the church, and
had outraged their deepest feelings.

6061.text:
He had schooled himself to be respectful to
the Judge, and then blundered into his front

6066.text:
door.
And all the time he had meant right,—and

6071.text:
yet, and yet, somehow he found it so hard
and strange to fit his old surroundings again,

6076.text:
to find his place in the world about him.
He could not remember that he used to have

6081.text:
any difficulty in the past, when life was
glad and gay.

6084.text:
The world seemed smooth and easy then.
Perhaps,—but his sister came to the kitchen

6091.text:
door just then and said the Judge awaited
him.

6095.text:
The Judge sat in the dining-room amid his
morning's mail, and he did not ask John to

6101.text:
sit down.
He plunged squarely into the business. "You've

6105.text:
come for the school, I suppose.
Well John, I want to speak to you plainly.

6110.text:
You know I'm a friend to your people.
I've helped you and your family, and would

6114.text:
have done more if you hadn't got the notion
of going off.

6117.text:
Now I like the colored people, and sympathize
with all their reasonable aspirations; but

6122.text:
you and I both know, John, that in this country
the Negro must remain subordinate, and can

6128.text:
never expect to be the equal of white men.
In their place, your people can be honest

6133.text:
and respectful; and God knows, I'll do what
I can to help them.

6137.text:
But when they want to reverse nature, and
rule white men, and marry white women, and

6141.text:
sit in my parlor, then, by God! we'll hold
them under if we have to lynch every Nigger

6147.text:
in the land.
Now, John, the question is, are you, with

6151.text:
your education and Northern notions, going
to accept the situation and teach the darkies

6157.text:
to be faithful servants and laborers as your
fathers were,—I knew your father, John,

6161.text:
he belonged to my brother, and he was a good
Nigger.

6164.text:
Well—well, are you going to be like him,
or are you going to try to put fool ideas

6169.text:
of rising and equality into these folks' heads,
and make them discontented and unhappy?"

6175.text:
"I am going to accept the situation, Judge
Henderson," answered John, with a brevity

6183.text:
that did not escape the keen old man.
He hesitated a moment, and then said shortly,

6189.text:
"Very well,—we'll try you awhile. Good-morning."
It was a full month after the opening of the

6199.text:
Negro school that the other John came home,
tall, gay, and headstrong.

6205.text:
The mother wept, the sisters sang.
The whole white town was glad.

6209.text:
A proud man was the Judge, and it was a goodly
sight to see the two swinging down Main Street

6214.text:
together.
And yet all did not go smoothly between them,

6218.text:
for the younger man could not and did not
veil his contempt for the little town, and

6223.text:
plainly had his heart set on New York.
Now the one cherished ambition of the Judge

6229.text:
was to see his son mayor of Altamaha, representative
to the legislature, and—who could say?—governor

6236.text:
of Georgia.
So the argument often waxed hot between them.

6240.text:
"Good heavens, father," the younger man would
say after dinner, as he lighted a cigar and

6245.text:
stood by the fireplace, "you surely don't
expect a young fellow like me to settle down

6249.text:
permanently in this—this God-forgotten town
with nothing but mud and Negroes?"

6255.text:
"I did," the Judge would answer laconically;
and on this particular day it seemed from

6262.text:
the gathering scowl that he was about to add
something more emphatic, but neighbors had

6267.text:
already begun to drop in to admire his son,
and the conversation drifted.

6271.text:
"Heah that John is livenin' things up at the
darky school," volunteered the postmaster,

6276.text:
after a pause.
"What now?" asked the Judge, sharply.

6281.text:
"Oh, nothin' in particulah,—just his almighty
air and uppish ways. B'lieve I did heah somethin'

6287.text:
about his givin' talks on the French Revolution,
equality, and such like.

6292.text:
He's what I call a dangerous Nigger."
"Have you heard him say anything out of the

6301.text:
way?"
"Why, no,—but Sally, our girl, told my wife

6302.text:
a lot of rot.
Then, too, I don't need to heah: a Nigger

6306.text:
what won't say 'sir' to a white man, or—"
"Who is this John?" interrupted the son.

6310.text:
"Why, it's little black John, Peggy's son,—your
old playfellow."

6315.text:
The young man's face flushed angrily, and
then he laughed.

6322.text:
"Oh," said he, "it's the darky that tried
to force himself into a seat beside the lady

6326.text:
I was escorting—"
But Judge Henderson waited to hear no more.

6331.text:
He had been nettled all day, and now at this
he rose with a half-smothered oath, took his

6336.text:
hat and cane, and walked straight to the schoolhouse.
For John, it had been a long, hard pull to

6342.text:
get things started in the rickety old shanty
that sheltered his school.

6345.text:
The Negroes were rent into factions for and
against him, the parents were careless, the

6350.text:
children irregular and dirty, and books, pencils,
and slates largely missing.

6355.text:
Nevertheless, he struggled hopefully on, and
seemed to see at last some glimmering of dawn.

6359.text:
The attendance was larger and the children
were a shade cleaner this week.

6366.text:
Even the booby class in reading showed a little
comforting progress.

6369.text:
So John settled himself with renewed patience
this afternoon.

6373.text:
"Now, Mandy," he said cheerfully, "that's
better; but you mustn't chop your words up

6380.text:
so: 'If—the-man—goes.' Why, your little
brother even wouldn't tell a story that way,

6386.text:
now would he?"
"Naw, suh, he cain't talk."

6390.text:
"All right; now let's try again: 'If the man—'
"John!"

6397.text:
The whole school started in surprise, and
the teacher half arose, as the red, angry

6402.text:
face of the Judge appeared in the open doorway.
"John, this school is closed.

6406.text:
You children can go home and get to work.
The white people of Altamaha are not spending

6411.text:
their money on black folks to have their heads
crammed with impudence and lies.

6415.text:
Clear out!
I'll lock the door myself."

6419.text:
Up at the great pillared house the tall young
son wandered aimlessly about after his father's

6425.text:
abrupt departure.
In the house there was little to interest

6429.text:
him; the books were old and stale, the local
newspaper flat, and the women had retired

6434.text:
with headaches and sewing. He tried a nap,
but it was too warm.

6440.text:
So he sauntered out into the fields, complaining
disconsolately, "Good Lord! how long will

6445.text:
this imprisonment last!"
He was not a bad fellow,—just a little spoiled

6452.text:
and self-indulgent, and as headstrong as his
proud father.

6456.text:
He seemed a young man pleasant to look upon,
as he sat on the great black stump at the

6459.text:
edge of the pines idly swinging his legs and
smoking.

6462.text:
"Why, there isn't even a girl worth getting
up a respectable flirtation with," he growled.

6469.text:
Just then his eye caught a tall, willowy figure
hurrying toward him on the narrow path.

6476.text:
He looked with interest at first, and then
burst into a laugh as he said, "Well, I declare,

6481.text:
if it isn't Jennie, the little brown kitchen-maid!
Why, I never noticed before what a trim little

6490.text:
Why, you haven't kissed me since I came home,"
he said gaily.

6496.text:
The young girl stared at him in surprise and
confusion,—faltered something inarticulate,

6501.text:
and attempted to pass.
But a wilful mood had seized the young idler,

6505.text:
and he caught at her arm.
Frightened, she slipped by; and half mischievously

6510.text:
he turned and ran after her through the tall
pines.

6516.text:
Yonder, toward the sea, at the end of the
path, came John slowly, with his head down.

6521.text:
He had turned wearily homeward from the schoolhouse;
then, thinking to shield his mother from the

6525.text:
blow, started to meet his sister as she came
from work and break the news of his dismissal

6530.text:
to her.
"I'll go away," he said slowly; "I'll go away

6535.text:
and find work, and send for them.
I cannot live here longer."

6538.text:
And then the fierce, buried anger surged up
into his throat.

6547.text:
He waved his arms and hurried wildly up the
path.

6552.text:
The great brown sea lay silent.
The air scarce breathed.

6555.text:
The dying day bathed the twisted oaks and
mighty pines in black and gold.

6561.text:
There came from the wind no warning, not a
whisper from the cloudless sky. There was

6566.text:
only a black man hurrying on with an ache
in his heart, seeing neither sun nor sea,

6572.text:
but starting as from a dream at the frightened
cry that woke the pines, to see his dark sister

6578.text:
struggling in the arms of a tall and fair-haired
man.

6582.text:
He said not a word, but, seizing a fallen
limb, struck him with all the pent-up hatred

6586.text:
of his great black arm, and the body lay white
and still beneath the pines, all bathed in

6594.text:
sunshine and in blood.
John looked at it dreamily, then walked back

6601.text:
to the house briskly, and said in a soft voice,
"Mammy, I'm going away—I'm going to be free."

6611.text:
She gazed at him dimly and faltered, "No'th,
honey, is yo' gwine No'th agin?"

6616.text:
He looked out where the North Star glistened
pale above the waters, and said, "Yes, mammy,

6625.text:
I'm going—North."
Then, without another word, he went out into

6631.text:
the narrow lane, up by the straight pines,
to the same winding path, and seated himself

6638.text:
on the great black stump, looking at the blood
where the body had lain. Yonder in the gray

6645.text:
past he had played with that dead boy, romping
together under the solemn trees.

6651.text:
The night deepened; he thought of the boys
at Johnstown.

6656.text:
He wondered how Brown had turned out, and
Carey? And Jones,—Jones?

6663.text:
Why, he was Jones, and he wondered what they
would all say when they knew, when they knew,

6672.text:
in that great long dining-room with its hundreds
of merry eyes.

6678.text:
Then as the sheen of the starlight stole over
him, he thought of the gilded ceiling of that

6683.text:
vast concert hall, heard stealing toward him
the faint sweet music of the swan. Hark! was

6691.text:
it music, or the hurry and shouting of men?
Yes, surely! Clear and high the faint sweet

6700.text:
melody rose and fluttered like a living thing,
so that the very earth trembled as with the

6705.text:
tramp of horses and murmur of angry men.
He leaned back and smiled toward the sea,

6713.text:
whence rose the strange melody, away from
the dark shadows where lay the noise of horses

6717.text:
galloping, galloping on.
With an effort he roused himself, bent forward,

6724.text:
and looked steadily down the pathway, softly
humming the "Song of the Bride,"—

6734.text:
"Freudig gefuhrt, ziehet dahin."
Amid the trees in the dim morning twilight

6743.text:
he watched their shadows dancing and heard
their horses thundering toward him, until

6748.text:
at last they came sweeping like a storm, and
he saw in front that haggard white-haired

6754.text:
man, whose eyes flashed red with fury.
Oh, how he pitied him,—pitied him,—and

6762.text:
wondered if he had the coiling twisted rope.
Then, as the storm burst round him, he rose

6768.text:
slowly to his feet and turned his closed eyes
toward the Sea.

6774.text:
And the world whistled in his ears.
End of Chapter XIII

Of the Sorrow Songs

6790.text:
To lay this body down;
I know moon-rise, I know star-rise;

6797.text:
I walk in the moonlight, I walk in the starlight;
I'll lie in the grave and stretch out my arms,

6803.text:
I'll go to judgment in the evening of the
day,

6807.text: And my soul and thy soul shall meet that day,

6809.text: When I lay this body down.

6813.text:
Negro Song
They that walked in darkness sang songs in

6833.text:
the olden days—Sorrow Songs—for they were
weary at heart.

6839.text:
And so before each thought that I have written
in this book I have set a phrase, a haunting

6845.text:
echo of these weird old songs in which the
soul of the black slave spoke to men. Ever

6851.text:
since I was a child these songs have stirred
me strangely.

6854.text:
They came out of the South unknown to me,
one by one, and yet at once I knew them as

6860.text:
of me and of mine.
Then in after years when I came to Nashville

6865.text:
I saw the great temple builded of these songs
towering over the pale city.

6870.text:
To me Jubilee Hall seemed ever made of the
songs themselves, and its bricks were red

6876.text:
with the blood and dust of toil. Out of them
rose for me morning, noon, and night, bursts

6881.text:
of wonderful melody, full of the voices of
my brothers and sisters, full of the voices

6887.text:
of the past.
Little of beauty has America given the world

6892.text:
save the rude grandeur God himself stamped
on her bosom; the human spirit in this new

6897.text:
world has expressed itself in vigor and ingenuity
rather than in beauty.

6903.text:
And so by fateful chance the Negro folk-song—the
rhythmic cry of the slave—stands to-day

6909.text:
not simply as the sole American music, but
as the most beautiful expression of human

6914.text:
experience born this side the seas. It has
been neglected, it has been, and is, half

6922.text:
despised, and above all it has been persistently
mistaken and misunderstood; but notwithstanding,

6928.text:
it still remains as the singular spiritual
heritage of the nation and the greatest gift

6932.text:
of the Negro people.
Away back in the thirties the melody of these

6939.text:
slave songs stirred the nation, but the songs
were soon half forgotten.

6944.text:
Some, like "Near the lake where drooped the
willow," passed into current airs and their

6949.text:
source was forgotten; others were caricatured
on the "minstrel" stage and their memory died

6956.text:
away.
Then in war-time came the singular Port Royal

6960.text:
experiment after the capture of Hilton Head,
and perhaps for the first time the North met

6965.text:
the Southern slave face to face and heart
to heart with no third witness.

6970.text:
The Sea Islands of the Carolinas, where they
met, were filled with a black folk of primitive

6974.text:
type, touched and moulded less by the world
about them than any others outside the Black

6979.text:
Belt.
Their appearance was uncouth, their language

6983.text:
funny, but their hearts were human and their
singing stirred men with a mighty power. Thomas

6988.text:
Wentworth Higginson hastened to tell of these
songs, and Miss McKim and others urged upon

6994.text:
the world their rare beauty.
But the world listened only half credulously

6999.text:
until the Fisk Jubilee Singers sang the slave
songs so deeply into the world's heart that

7005.text:
it can never wholly forget them again.
There was once a blacksmith's son born at

7012.text:
Cadiz, New York, who in the changes of time
taught school in Ohio and helped defend Cincinnati

7017.text:
from Kirby Smith.
Then he fought at Chancellorsville and Gettysburg

7022.text:
and finally served in the Freedmen's Bureau
at Nashville.

7026.text:
Here he formed a Sunday-school class of black
children in 1866, and sang with them and taught

7031.text:
them to sing.
And then they taught him to sing, and when

7037.text:
once the glory of the Jubilee songs passed
into the soul of George L. White, he knew

7043.text:
his life-work was to let those Negroes sing
to the world as they had sung to him.

7049.text:
So in 1871 the pilgrimage of the Fisk Jubilee
Singers began.

7055.text:
North to Cincinnati they rode,—four half-clothed
black boys and five girl-women,—led by a

7061.text:
man with a cause and a purpose. They stopped
at Wilberforce, the oldest of Negro schools,

7067.text:
where a black bishop blessed them.
Then they went, fighting cold and starvation,

7073.text:
shut out of hotels, and cheerfully sneered
at, ever northward; and ever the magic of

7078.text:
their song kept thrilling hearts, until a
burst of applause in the Congregational Council

7083.text:
at Oberlin revealed them to the world.
They came to New York and Henry Ward Beecher

7090.text:
dared to welcome them, even though the metropolitan
dailies sneered at his "Nigger Minstrels."

7097.text:
So their songs conquered till they sang across
the land and across the sea, before Queen

7103.text:
and Kaiser, in Scotland and Ireland, Holland
and Switzerland.

7108.text:
Seven years they sang, and brought back a
hundred and fifty thousand dollars to found

7112.text:
Fisk University.
Since their day they have been imitated—sometimes

7116.text:
well, by the singers of Hampton and Atlanta,
sometimes ill, by straggling quartettes. Caricature

7123.text:
has sought again to spoil the quaint beauty
of the music, and has filled the air with

7127.text:
many debased melodies which vulgar ears scarce
know from the real.

7132.text:
But the true Negro folk-song still lives in
the hearts of those who have heard them truly

7137.text:
sung and in the hearts of the Negro people.
What are these songs, and what do they mean?

7143.text:
I know little of music and can say nothing
in technical phrase, but I know something

7149.text:
of men, and knowing them, I know that these
songs are the articulate message of the slave

7155.text:
to the world.
They tell us in these eager days that life

7159.text:
was joyous to the black slave, careless and
happy.

7162.text:
I can easily believe this of some, of many.
But not all the past South, though it rose

7169.text:
from the dead, can gainsay the heart-touching
witness of these songs.

7174.text:
They are the music of an unhappy people, of
the children of disappointment; they tell

7180.text:
of death and suffering and unvoiced longing
toward a truer world, of misty wanderings

7186.text:
and hidden ways.
The songs are indeed the siftings of centuries;

7191.text:
the music is far more ancient than the words,
and in it we can trace here and there signs

7196.text:
of development.
My grandfather's grandmother was seized by

7201.text:
an evil Dutch trader two centuries ago; and
coming to the valleys of the Hudson and Housatonic,

7206.text:
black, little, and lithe, she shivered and
shrank in the harsh north winds, looked longingly

7213.text:
at the hills, and often crooned a heathen
melody to the child between her knees, thus:

7220.text:
Do ba-na co-ba, ge-ne me, ge-ne me!
Do ba-na co-ba, ge-ne me, ge-ne me!

7230.text:
Ben d' nu-li, nu-li, nu-li, ben d' le.
The child sang it to his children and they

7243.text:
to their children's children, and so two hundred
years it has travelled down to us and we sing

7249.text:
it to our children, knowing as little as our
fathers what its words may mean, but knowing

7254.text:
well the meaning of its music.
This was primitive African music; it may be

7259.text:
seen in larger form in the strange chant which
heralds "The Coming of John":

7263.text: "You may bury me in the East,

7266.text: You may bury me in the West,

7267.text:
But I'll hear the trumpet sound in that morning,"
—the voice of exile.

7274.text:
Ten master songs, more or less, one may pluck
from the forest of melody-songs of undoubted

7281.text:
Negro origin and wide popular currency, and
songs peculiarly characteristic of the slave.

7289.text:
One of these I have just mentioned.
Another whose strains begin this book is "Nobody

7294.text:
knows the trouble I've seen."
When, struck with a sudden poverty, the United

7299.text:
States refused to fulfill its promises of
land to the freedmen, a brigadier-general

7303.text:
went down to the Sea Islands to carry the
news.

7306.text:
An old woman on the outskirts of the throng
began singing this song; all the mass joined

7312.text:
with her, swaying.
And the soldier wept.

7317.text:
The third song is the cradle-song of death
which all men know,-"Swing low, sweet chariot,"—whose

7322.text:
bars begin the life story of "Alexander Crummell."
Then there is the song of many waters, "Roll,

7328.text:
Jordan, roll," a mighty chorus with minor
cadences.

7333.text:
There were many songs of the fugitive like
that which opens "The Wings of Atalanta,"

7338.text:
and the more familiar "Been a-listening."
The seventh is the song of the End and the

7344.text:
Beginning—"My Lord, what a mourning! when
the stars begin to fall"; a strain of this

7349.text:
is placed before "The Dawn of Freedom."
The song of groping—"My way's cloudy"—begins

7355.text:
"The Meaning of Progress"; the ninth is the
song of this chapter—"Wrestlin' Jacob, the

7361.text:
day is a-breaking,"—a paean of hopeful strife.
The last master song is the song of songs—"Steal

7368.text:
away,"—sprung from "The Faith of the Fathers."
There are many others of the Negro folk-songs

7375.text:
as striking and characteristic as these, as,
for instance, the three strains in the third,

7381.text:
eighth, and ninth chapters; and others I am
sure could easily make a selection on more

7385.text:
scientific principles.
There are, too, songs that seem to be a step

7389.text:
removed from the more primitive types: there
is the maze-like medley, "Bright sparkles,"

7396.text:
one phrase of which heads "The Black Belt";
the Easter carol, "Dust, dust and ashes";

7405.text:
the dirge, "My mother's took her flight and
gone home"; and that burst of melody hovering

7410.text:
over "The Passing of the First-Born"—"I
hope my mother will be there in that beautiful

7415.text:
world on high."
These represent a third step in the development

7420.text:
of the slave song, of which "You may bury
me in the East" is the first, and songs like

7427.text:
"March on" (chapter six) and "Steal away"
are the second.

7433.text:
The first is African music, the second Afro-American,
while the third is a blending of Negro music

7440.text:
with the music heard in the foster land.
The result is still distinctively Negro and

7446.text:
the method of blending original, but the elements
are both Negro and Caucasian.

7451.text:
One might go further and find a fourth step
in this development, where the songs of white

7455.text:
America have been distinctively influenced
by the slave songs or have incorporated whole

7460.text:
phrases of Negro melody, as "Swanee River"
and "Old Black Joe." Side by side, too, with

7468.text:
the growth has gone the debasements and imitations—the
Negro "minstrel" songs, many of the "gospel"

7476.text:
hymns, and some of the contemporary "coon"
songs,—a mass of music in which the novice

7481.text:
may easily lose himself and never find the
real Negro melodies.

7488.text:
In these songs, I have said, the slave spoke
to the world.

7492.text:
Such a message is naturally veiled and half
articulate.

7496.text:
Words and music have lost each other and new
and cant phrases of a dimly understood theology

7501.text:
have displaced the older sentiment.
Once in a while we catch a strange word of

7506.text:
an unknown tongue, as the "Mighty Myo," which
figures as a river of death; more often slight

7512.text:
words or mere doggerel are joined to music
of singular sweetness.

7517.text:
Purely secular songs are few in number, partly
because many of them were turned into hymns

7523.text:
by a change of words, partly because the frolics
were seldom heard by the stranger, and the

7529.text:
music less often caught.
Of nearly all the songs, however, the music

7534.text:
is distinctly sorrowful.
The ten master songs I have mentioned tell

7539.text:
in word and music of trouble and exile, of
strife and hiding; they grope toward some

7547.text:
unseen power and sigh for rest in the End.
The words that are left to us are not without

7555.text:
interest, and, cleared of evident dross, they
conceal much of real poetry and meaning beneath

7561.text:
conventional theology and unmeaning rhapsody.
Like all primitive folk, the slave stood near

7568.text:
to Nature's heart.
Life was a "rough and rolling sea" like the

7572.text:
brown Atlantic of the Sea Islands; the "Wilderness"
was the home of God, and the "lonesome valley"

7578.text:
led to the way of life. "Winter'll soon be
over," was the picture of life and death to

7585.text:
a tropical imagination.
The sudden wild thunderstorms of the South

7590.text:
awed and impressed the Negroes,—at times
the rumbling seemed to them "mournful," at

7598.text:
"My Lord calls me,
He calls me by the thunder,

7604.text:
The trumpet sounds it in my soul."
The monotonous toil and exposure is painted

7610.text:
in many words.
One sees the ploughmen in the hot, moist furrow,

7617.text: Dere's no sun to burn you,

7622.text:
I want to go home."
The bowed and bent old man cries, with thrice-repeated

7629.text:
"O Lord, keep me from sinking down,"
and he rebukes the devil of doubt who can

7637.text:
"Jesus is dead and God's gone away."
Yet the soul-hunger is there, the restlessness

7645.text:
of the savage, the wail of the wanderer, and
the plaint is put in one little phrase:

7652.text:
My soul wants something that's new, that's
new

7660.text:
Over the inner thoughts of the slaves and
their relations one with another the shadow

7664.text:
of fear ever hung, so that we get but glimpses
here and there, and also with them, eloquent

7671.text:
omissions and silences.
Mother and child are sung, but seldom father;

7679.text:
fugitive and weary wanderer call for pity
and affection, but there is little of wooing

7684.text:
and wedding; the rocks and the mountains are
well known, but home is unknown.

7693.text:
Strange blending of love and helplessness
sings through the refrain:

7700.text:
Been waggin' at de hill so long;
'Bout time she cross over,

7704.text:
Git home bime-by."
Elsewhere comes the cry of the "motherless"

7710.text:
and the "Farewell, farewell, my only child."
Love-songs are scarce and fall into two categories—the

7718.text:
frivolous and light, and the sad.
Of deep successful love there is ominous silence,

7726.text:
and in one of the oldest of these songs there
is a depth of history and meaning:

7732.text:
Poor Ro-sy, poor gal; Poor Ro-sy,
poor gal; Ro-sy break my poor heart,

7747.text:
Heav'n shall-a-be my home.
A black woman said of the song, "It can't

7754.text:
be sung without a full heart and a troubled
sperrit."

7761.text:
The same voice sings here that sings in the
German folk-song:

7765.text:
"Jetz Geh i' an's brunele, trink' aber net."
Of death the Negro showed little fear, but

7773.text:
talked of it familiarly and even fondly as
simply a crossing of the waters, perhaps—who

7779.text:
knows?—back to his ancient forests again.
Later days transfigured his fatalism, and

7787.text: amid the dust and dirt the toiler sang:

7789.text: "Dust, dust and ashes, fly over my grave,

7794.text:
But the Lord shall bear my spirit home."
The things evidently borrowed from the surrounding

7801.text:
world undergo characteristic change when they
enter the mouth of the slave. Especially is

7806.text:
this true of Bible phrases.
"Weep, O captive daughter of Zion," is quaintly

7811.text:
turned into "Zion, weep-a-low," and the wheels
of Ezekiel are turned every way in the mystic

7819.text:
dreaming of the slave, till he says:
"There's a little wheel a-turnin' in-a-my

7823.text:
heart."
As in olden time, the words of these hymns

7829.text:
were improvised by some leading minstrel of
the religious band.

7833.text:
The circumstances of the gathering, however,
the rhythm of the songs, and the limitations

7837.text:
of allowable thought, confined the poetry
for the most part to single or double lines,

7843.text:
and they seldom were expanded to quatrains
or longer tales, although there are some few

7848.text:
examples of sustained efforts, chiefly paraphrases
of the Bible.

7853.text:
Three short series of verses have always attracted
me,—the one that heads this chapter, of

7860.text:
one line of which Thomas Wentworth Higginson
has fittingly said, "Never, it seems to me,

7864.text:
since man first lived and suffered was his
infinite longing for peace uttered more plaintively."

7871.text:
The second and third are descriptions of the
Last Judgment,—the one a late improvisation,

7877.text: with some traces of outside influence:

7880.text: "Oh, the stars in the elements are falling,

7883.text: And the moon drips away into blood,

7885.text:
And the ransomed of the Lord are returning
unto God,

7889.text:
Blessed be the name of the Lord."
And the other earlier and homelier picture

7899.text: Then you'll hear the horn they blow,

7901.text: Then you'll hear the trumpet sound,

7906.text: Trumpet sound for rich and poor,

7910.text:
Trumpet sound for you and me."
Through all the sorrow of the Sorrow Songs

7917.text:
there breathes a hope—a faith in the ultimate
justice of things.

7922.text:
The minor cadences of despair change often
to triumph and calm confidence.

7928.text:
Sometimes it is faith in life, sometimes a
faith in death, sometimes assurance of boundless

7935.text:
justice in some fair world beyond.
But whichever it is, the meaning is always

7942.text:
clear: that sometime, somewhere, men will
judge men by their souls and not by their

7948.text:
skins.
Is such a hope justified?

7952.text:
Do the Sorrow Songs sing true?
The silently growing assumption of this age

7958.text:
is that the probation of races is past, and
that the backward races of to-day are of proven

7963.text:
inefficiency and not worth the saving.
Such an assumption is the arrogance of peoples

7970.text:
irreverent toward Time and ignorant of the
deeds of men.

7974.text:
A thousand years ago such an assumption, easily
possible, would have made it difficult for

7980.text:
the Teuton to prove his right to life. Two
thousand years ago such dogmatism, readily

7986.text:
welcome, would have scouted the idea of blond
races ever leading civilization.

7992.text:
So wofully unorganized is sociological knowledge
that the meaning of progress, the meaning

7997.text:
of "swift" and "slow" in human doing, and
the limits of human perfectability, are veiled,

8003.text:
unanswered sphinxes on the shores of science.
Why should AEschylus have sung two thousand

8009.text:
years before Shakespeare was born?
Why has civilization flourished in Europe,

8015.text:
and flickered, flamed, and died in Africa?
So long as the world stands meekly dumb before

8021.text:
such questions, shall this nation proclaim
its ignorance and unhallowed prejudices by

8026.text:
denying freedom of opportunity to those who
brought the Sorrow Songs to the Seats of the

8034.text:
How came it yours?
Before the Pilgrims landed we were here.

8040.text:
Here we have brought our three gifts and mingled
them with yours: a gift of story and song—soft,

8046.text:
stirring melody in an ill-harmonized and unmelodious
land; the gift of sweat and brawn to beat

8052.text:
back the wilderness, conquer the soil, and
lay the foundations of this vast economic

8057.text:
empire two hundred years earlier than your
weak hands could have done it; the third,

8063.text:
a gift of the Spirit.
Around us the history of the land has centred

8069.text:
for thrice a hundred years; out of the nation's
heart we have called all that was best to

8077.text:
throttle and subdue all that was worst; fire
and blood, prayer and sacrifice, have billowed

8084.text:
over this people, and they have found peace
only in the altars of the God of Right.

8091.text:
Nor has our gift of the Spirit been merely
passive.

8094.text:
Actively we have woven ourselves with the
very warp and woof of this nation,—we fought

8099.text:
their battles, shared their sorrow, mingled
our blood with theirs, and generation after

8104.text:
generation have pleaded with a headstrong,
careless people to despise not Justice, Mercy,

8112.text:
and Truth, lest the nation be smitten with
a curse.

8115.text:
Our song, our toil, our cheer, and warning
have been given to this nation in blood-brotherhood.

8127.text:
Are not these gifts worth the giving?
Is not this work and striving?

8135.text:
Would America have been America without her
Negro people?

8141.text:
Even so is the hope that sang in the songs
of my fathers well sung.

8147.text:
If somewhere in this whirl and chaos of things
there dwells Eternal Good, pitiful yet masterful,

8155.text:
then anon in His good time America shall rend
the Veil and the prisoned shall go free.

8161.text:
Free, free as the sunshine trickling down
the morning into these high windows of mine,

8168.text:
free as yonder fresh young voices welling
up to me from the caverns of brick and mortar

8173.text:
below—swelling with song, instinct with
life, tremulous treble and darkening bass.

8179.text:
My children, my little children, are singing
to the sunshine, and thus they sing:

8186.text:
Let us cheer the wea-ry trav-el-ler,
Cheer the wea-ry trav-el-ler, Let us

8195.text:
cheer the wea-ry trav-el-ler

his face toward the Morning, and goes his

8228.text:
this my book fall not still-born into the

Let there spring, Gentle One, from out its

8240.text:
to reap the harvest wonderful.

truth, and seventy millions sigh for the righteousness

8253.text:
when human brotherhood is mockery and a snare.

turn the tangle straight, and these crooked
